A COMEDY: Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL, IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: PRINTED FOR G. ROBINSON, No. 25, PATER-NOSTER-ROW; AND P. NORBURY, BRENTFORD.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: THREE or four years having elapsed since the representation of the fol∣lowing trifle, it will, no doubt, be thought extraordinary, that it should make its appearance in print just at the time when so capital a production as The SCHOOL for SCANDAL en∣grosses all theatrical attention: in some degree to excuse the ill-timing of this publication, the author assures the public, that the copy-right was disposed of, and some sheets of it in the press, before that Comedy appeared; otherwise they would never have been troubled with this apo∣logy, or the cause of it.

TO THE LADIES and GENTLEMEN, Who, by their admirable performance of this first essay, and excellent de∣livery of the prologue and epilogue to it, obtained such applause to them, as in themselves they could not merit, The MAID of KENT Is most gratefully inscribed, by their much obliged Servant,

LG.L: WHEN a melodious lark, ascending, sings,
The wide expanse with shrilly echoes rings;
'Till, strongly winging his aerial way,
To sight he's lost, warbling his heav'n-tun'd lay!
Not so, when the young bird first 'ttempts a flight,
Emerging from his nest to dazzling light—
With flutt'ring pinions, half-form'd notes, dim'd eyes,
From the too pow'rful glare, he, trembling, hies
To some thick wood, low copse, or shady grove,
Where he, secure from birds of prey, may rove;
Where safely he may try his feeble wings,
There flits from spray to spray, and faintly sings:
Patient remains 'till strength and art are won,
Then soars and warbles 'gainst the noon-day sun!
But, when he ventures first t'explore the sky,
Should critic-buzzard, hawk, or kite be nigh,
Skimming and winding round, then on him dart,
His beak and talons dig into his heart;
No more he sings, no more can ever fly,
His artless song and self together die!
So will it fare with our green-bird or sparrow,
If, grov'ling found, you o'er him draw the harrow;
No more he'll chirrup his insipid note,
Or vainly gurgle his discordant throat:
O loss of losses!—ne'er to be recover'd—
A green-bird in a furrow you have smother'd!
But say you're merciful, and, 'stead of killing
The vent'rous fool, to rear him should be willing;
Pleas'd, he'll crack rape-seed, bucket raise of water,
T' amuse yourself, spouse, son, and pretty daughter;
And while he grunsell picks, or chickweed eats,
Will, chirping, thank each gen'rous heart that treats;
May learn the linnet's, lark's, canary's song,
His tuneful life if kindly you prolong;
And strive each hour t'improve his simple lay,
In clearer strains your favours to repay!

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: Scene—Sir Thomas Richacre's Seat, near the Sea∣coast, in Kent.

DIV2.HEAD: ACT I. Scene a Study in Sir Thomas Richacre's House. Doctor Goodman and Emily are discovered sitting: the Doctor shutting a Book, they pre∣sently rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. GOODMAN.
SP.P: HERE, madam, if you please, we'll con∣clude the labour of the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Call it rather the pleasure of the day, sir,—for such it is to me, I assure you—to you indeed, sir, I fear it must be otherwise—the instruction of a silly girl, no doubt, is painful and tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Pardon me, madam, I did not call it labour in that sense; so far am I from think∣ing it irksome, the hours I pass in this our every morning's exercise, and the duties of my holy function, are the happiest of my life:—for, believe me, were you my own child, instead of my honour'd patron's, I could not love you better!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Nor do I think Sir Thomas's affection (altho' the best of fathers) exceeds the very pa∣ternal regard you have ever been pleased to express for me—and—I know not why—I
think I feel not a more filial love for him, than for yourself, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Dear madam, say not so:—the many hours we pass together in our delightful studies, beget in you a customary regard— think it no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Perhaps it is no more, sir, nay, it cannot—for never had a child a kinder parent!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Nor ever had a man a truer friend! Indeed, so general is his goodness, he might be a pattern for mankind:—he never saw an infant without a parent's fondness, or a grey head, but, like a child, he honour'd it!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha! what, hard at it?—What is it?—Ethics or mathematics, astrology or the∣ology?—'tis a thousand pities, Doctor, your pupil is a girl, otherwise she would certainly be a bishop in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Perhaps not, papa;—you see Dr. Goodman, with as much piety, learning, good sense, and, I am sure, as good a heart as any, has hitherto attained to no greater dignities than rector of this parish, your chaplain, sir, and my tutor.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Were I, madam, what you are pleased to say of me, it does not at all follow I should ever be so exalted.—There are, no doubt, an infinitely greater number of deserving ministers than there are mitres, or even inferior dignities; but whoever has attained to that of an honest man, will feel, that church or state can never raise him higher!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I think so too, Doctor; and, in that respect, there is not a more exalted character than yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Heaven forbid, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: But all this while I forget your boy, Doctor.—I made my morning's airing shorter than usual, that I might be in the way when he arrived.—He is not come yet, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: No, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Does young Mr. Goodman come home from Oxford to day, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Yes, madam, I expect him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Bless me! I thought he was not to have come till next week, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Yes, yes, he'll be here to day, and then you may have a new tutor, for I suppose you have almost tir'd your old one.—I war∣rant, by this time, he can speak Greek as well as his father; what think you, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I not only think that of him, sir, but, were he not my own, I could be bold to say, he is the most accomplished youth I ever saw, and, add to that—the best!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, ay, George is a good boy!— ay, and a clever one too—every body says so as well as yourself:—but if they did not, the crow, you know, always thinks her own young whitest, ha, ha, ha!—Let me see, [looking at his watch] 'tis past one,—will the rogue be here to dinner, think you?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I expect him every moment, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Od! I wish he was come! I have not seen him this age:—and are not you glad he is coming, Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Yes, indeed, sir, very glad—for I think him a most amiable young man; and
have often thought it a thousand pities he is not heir to a good fortune; as this idolatrous world of ours, still worshipping a golden calf, would value him much more for inheriting a fund of wealth than virtues:—and a rich cox∣comb is oftner proposed to us poor girls, than the most deserving of our affections, whose me∣rits are not back'd with that powerful recom∣mendation—a great estate!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: It's very true, my dear,—too often the case, I must confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And I make no doubt, but even our ridiculous worthless neighbour, Lord Sealand's addresses, would be esteemed an honour, and plain George Goodman's, an affront, to most great families in the kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, he is a peer of the realm, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: True, papa; and there are very few so ill-bred, as to think a coronet may sometimes cover a weak head, or a glittering star, a bad heart!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha! well said, my little sati∣rist!—We are to be honour'd with his lord∣ship's company to day at dinner, on purpose to see George.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: His lordship has been always kind enough to take great notice of my poor boy.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That is the only proof of understand∣ing he ever gave—and, but for that, he would be intolerable, with his unaccountable whims and caprices.—Now own, papa, don't you think it a strange amusement he has lately taken to, keeping sailing vessels, to be so often tossing about on the sea as he is?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why ay, child, I think it rather too boisterous to be called pleasure; but he seldom makes a much longer trip than just across to Calais, to furnish himself with some of their knicknacks and fopperies.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Right, papa; for such a finical wa∣terfly is he, that, when on shore, he lays out more money in powder and perfumes in a week, than, I fear, he gives to the poor in a year.—I never see him, papa, but I think of beau Mizen in the play. Ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well, but, Emily, my dear, you, of all people in the world, should not be so severe upon him: he's a very warm admirer of you, you know; and has almost ask'd my con∣sent to marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: He is not a bit more in my good graces for that, I assure you, papa; for, could he obtain your consent, I believe he'd care very little whether he had mine or not.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: But Sir Thomas, I am persuaded, madam, will never grant one without the other.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That I confide in, sir.—I suppose I shall be teiz'd to death with his supercilious nonsense to day, which he gives me to under∣stand he means for courtship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And are not you delighted at the very idea of being his lady?—Countess of Sealand!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Not I, indeed, papa; lud! lud! what a character! a foppish sailor! a compound of tar and civet! faugh!—I'd sooner marry our honest Old Metre yonder, and be dame to the clerk of the parish.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! here comes the old psalm-singer as fast as he can hobble.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Poor good old man! he's worth a court-calendar full of such lords!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Your reverence! your reverence!— goodlack, I most humbly crave your worship's pardon for my abrupt intrusion, [to Sir Thomas] but I come a joyful harbinger! As I am a sin∣ner, sir, your well-beloved son is just arrived. [to the Doctor.]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Is he faith, old Sternhold?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Yes, in truth, your worship, or may I never set another stave.

SP.SPEAKER: Emity.
SP.P: [Looking out.] O lud, ay! he is just stepping out of the post-chaise—bless me—what a figure I am!—I—I beg pardon, sir, but in∣deed I can't stay—I must go and make myself a little more fit to be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Did you observe the girl, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Most heedfully, sir—and fear—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: He approacheth, your honours, he approacheth!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, here he comes, sure enough.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Your blessing, sir, [kneeling to Dr. Goodman.]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Heaven grant thee grace!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: My honour'd patron! my second fa∣ther! [to Sir Thomas] I can't resist an impulse that throws me at your feet, and bids me beg your blessing too!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Heaven bless and preserve you, my good lad!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: My dear father, forgive this transport —I fear it hurries me into a neglect, I'd sooner die than willingly be guilty of —but—this meeting overpowers me!—don't be offended, sir, [to Sir Thomas] at the frankness of a poor lad like me—indeed I am very happy to see you, sir! I hope both you, sir, and my dear father, are as well as—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well? odzookers! who can be ill and look such a ruddy-cheek'd rogue as you in the face?—faith, you look bravely, my lad!— and a devilish handsome young dog you are grown! rare work, I warrant, he has made at Oxford, Doctor! how many dozen have you left crying their eyes out, eh, George?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You are merry, sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Sir. Thom.
SP.P: Well, but—joking apart—have you left ne'er a little tender soul breaking her heart after you;—a sweetheart, eh, George? for I'll engage you have got one, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: To what end, sir, so young and un∣provided for, as I am?—But, excuse me, sir, for interrupting you by hoping Miss Richacre is well.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, Emily is pure hearty, and as reserv'd as yourself—She wont confess the power of the little blind boy any more than you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: The longer she is, sir, before she makes her choice, we may reasonably hope the better it will be.—But, I believe, sir, she may wait long indeed, before she finds one to de∣serve her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Odzookers, George, that's a civiler thing than ever I heard Lord Sealand say of her, with all his courtship.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Lord Sealand! [aside] I—I hope, sir, I do not offend in speaking my sentiments so freely?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Offend! no, no, boy—I like you the better for speaking your thoughts—I wish all mankind did so, they would not be the worse for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Then, with your worship's indulgence, I can withhold no longer—As I am an unwor∣thy sinner, sir, [to George] I am more delighted to behold you than a full congregation! and that is the delight of my old heart.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What, my good old friend! nothing but my extreme joy at seeing my honour'd pa∣rent and protector, could have made me over∣look you—I am very glad to see you—I hope you are well! [taking Metre kindly by the hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: In troth, the better for seeing you well, sir! [wiping his eyes.]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Ah, my old playfellow, "Thou hast born me on this back a thousand times!"

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: And a pleasant load thou wert, my ever gentle task-master! he, he, he!—and, in like sportful sort, although I am waxen old, I hope to live to bear your tender offspring!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, my poor Yorick! time will, I fear, bear you away first!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
Not so neither, George—for, as my mother used to say to me, those eyes of yours will make many a pretty girl's heart ach—so, don't be timorous, lad, but look about you; and, if you take a liking to a girl, let her be who she may, attack her boldly—I am a
whimsical old fellow, and if I take it into my head, may make you worth her having.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Sir, I fear your goodness will—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Pho, pho, be quiet, Doctor—you know I am not (like too many in the world) easily talked out of a good design, or into a bad one—but, tell us, George, sincerely, now we are upon the subject, have you really ne'er a sweetheart at Oxford?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, I assure you, sir.—I never saw a face there that made the least impression on me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And you are heart-whole, ha?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: As when I left this house, sir! [sighing aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, how have you pass'd your time, lad? always at your studies?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Pretty constantly, sir—the only re∣turn in my power for your great bounty to me, was the making a proper use of it.—But, if I may be so bold, sir, I think you mentioned something of Lord Sealand's having paid his addresses to Miss Richacre.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, George, I believe I might—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But I think, sir, you said too, that Miss Emily had not hitherto confess'd any particular inclination—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, no—but he's very rich— and when a suitor is both wealthy and noble, you know—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Very true, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
Not that I believe Emily likes him a jot better for those accidental advan∣tages, as she calls them—She and I are much of a mind about him; for, in my opinion,
he is but a frothy kind of a spark, like too many of the present age—and it is paying you no compliment, George, to say such a lad as you are, is worth a score such as Lord Sealand. [George bows respectfully.]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I fear, sir, what you are pleased to say of my poor boy will make him vain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Vain of what such an old fellow as I say! no, no,—If Emily had said as much indeed—but, Doctor, I must rob you of George's company a little—come, boy,—you must go and ask my girl how she is—she'll be glad to see you, I'm sure—She just saw you alight, and scamper'd away to set her cap strait, or some such important matter—Come along, my boy, and I'll promise you a kiss for your pains.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Will you excuse me a few moments, my dear sir, while I pay my respects to Miss Richacre?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Ay, ay, attend Sir Thomas by all means—meantime, I'll step and see a poor cottager hard by, who, Metre has just been telling me, is very ill.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You are as humane as ever, sir, heaven bless you!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: And you too, my dear boy!

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt Dr. Goodman and George severally.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P:
Amen! and heaven be with you both! for such a father and such a son, are hardly to be parallel'd!—No marvel his good worship is so well pleased in ye—he, whese benignity extendeth even unto my unworthy self, and my poor child, Martha; whom he hath most benevolently reared, as waiting-maid
unto his fair daughter, from childhood even unto womanhood—and, in commiseration of my forlorn condition, when my loving help∣mate, Rebecca, departed this transitory life, bountifully took me to end my days in peace in his most hospitable mansion!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am, there's nobody here but my father—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Whom seeketh her good ladyship, Martha?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I thought Mr. Goodman had been here.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: No, madam—his reverence is gone to visit the afflicted.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O, no—I don't mean the Doctor, but George Goodman—I met his father this mo∣ment, and he said he was this way.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Good madam, I most humbly crave forgiveness for my misapprehension—my dearly beloved young master departed hence but even now indeed, to accompany his worship, in order to pay his most dutiful respects unto your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Run, Patty—tell my papa I came down the other stairs, and am here.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: So please your ladyship, I will ac∣quaint his worship forthwith.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Thank you, Mr. Metre.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: I long for the sweet young pair to meet methinks!
SP.L: Would it might be never to part again—
That I devoutly pray, and to it add—Amen!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And so, Patty, you did see him, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, I just had a peep at him as he passed thro' the hall, and he did look so handsome you can't think.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I wish you are not in love with him, girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ah, madam! if I was as much his betters as he is mine, I'd soon tell him a piece of my mind.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Why really the youth's not amiss— I had a glimpse of him myself, and think him considerably improved, I must confess—his complexion more florid, and air more lively than when he left us.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ay, ma'am, that he is, more lively and more lovely too than ever; and so you would say, ma'am, I am sure, if you spoke your thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed! and pray how came you so well acquainted with my thoughts?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Why, ma'am, the dressing glass dis∣covered them to me—for you have look'd more in it since you knew young Mr. Goodman was arrived, than ever I knew you in all my life before—And I'll be whipt if you don't wish to appear as handsome in his eyes as he does in yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O you wicked girl, how can you say so?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Indeed, ma'am, if I was as rich as your ladyship, and we were both at our own disposal, I fancy we should puzzle the poor young gentleman which to choose—for his choice he might have, that's certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And, in that case, you think he'd be puzzled which to choose?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: O, dear ma'am, I had quite forgot one thing—that is—If I was as beautiful as your ladyship.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O, your ladyship's most obedient! [curtsying] and so you have quite forgot your sweetheart, William?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: William?—yes—no, ma'am—that is —O gemini, ma'am, here the sweet gentleman comes as sure as a gun!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Eh! what! where?

DIV2.STAGE: Sir Thomas Richacre and George enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Here, Emily, my girl, where are you? I was just going to storm your dressing room as old Amen overtook me—I have brought an old acquaintance to see you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: With your leave, sir— [offering to salute Emily.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, ay, kiss her, boy, kiss her!— and kiss him, girl! you two must not be strange.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Madam!—I—I hope— [saluting her.]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Sir!—I am—very— [both hesitate thro' confusion.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
Heyday! Madam—I hope—and, Sir, I am very—and there they both stop!— why what ail you both? you are not tongue∣tied sure all on a sudden?—Pray, sir,—what may you hope?—and, ma'am,—what are you very?—come, come, I fancy I can explain the matter—I suppose, George, if the truth was known, you hope to get another kiss—and you, Emily, are very willing to give it him! well,
well, with all my heart, never heed me—kiss her again, boy, kiss her again!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I beg pardon for—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Pho, pho, kiss her again, I tell you—I insist upon it—and then, perhaps, you'll recover your speech a little.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: [Saluting her again] I am so over∣joy'd, madam—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Sir, I am extremely— [They stand bow∣ing and curtsying confusedly▪]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: [To Sir Thom.] Dear heart, sir, I hope you won't be angry, but indeed I cant hold my tongue any longer—You're welcome to Kent, sir! I hope you are well, sir? [Curtsying to George.]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Very well, I thank you, Patty.—I am glad to see you—I hope you are well?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Pretty well, 'thank you, sir; how do you do?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why look you there now—I war∣rant Mistress Patt could hold on a—how d'ye do, sir? and a—pretty well, thank you, sir! till this day fortnight; [mimicking Patty] while you stand as mute as an Egyptian mummy.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Dear papa, forgive me.—Sir—I beg your pardon, but indeed I was so glad to see you, I had scarce power to tell you so!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You have bereft me, madam, of re∣ply, by saying the very words I would have utter'd if I could—may I flatter myself so far as to think—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: O yes, indeed, sir, you may flatter yourself—for my lady and I are both very glad to see you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, you chatter-box! I don't know any business you have here.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Dear heart, sir! I did but just speak —Chatter-box!—I wish I had been as cunning as some folks, and held my tongue, I might then have been kiss'd a little as well as some other people. [aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Pray, papa, excuse her—she always seem'd to have so great respect for Mr. Good∣man, and was so desirous now of seeing him, that I gave her leave to come with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: So please your worship, the right honourable the Earl of Sealand is just alight∣ing from his gilded cha-ri-ot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I'll go to him directly—children, I'll leave you to yourselves a little—you'll find your tongues, perhaps, when my back's turn'd —but, George, you have not much time to spare—Lord Sealand will be enquiring for you, so get dress'd as soon as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I will, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Come along then, old Pitch-pipe, and young madam Prate-a-pace!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: We follow your good and merry worship! ha, ha, ha! Martha, my child, come your ways.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I'll come presently, father—I am in great hopes he will kiss me yet!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Presently will not do, child, come now! [aside to her] Wilt thou never learn more manners than to hearken unto gentlefolks' discourse? an eves-dropper! fie for shame! get thee gone about thy business, that's my good girl.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: [aside] Psha! fiddle, faddle! how provoking this is! now I am sure I sha'n't get a kiss.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: [to Emily] Your honour's very hum∣ble servant! heaven bless you, my sweet young master!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And you too, my good old friend!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Just such a lovely pair were those first formed—ah! would your conditions were as equal! then might I hope, ere long, unto your nuptial benediction, most joyfully to cry Amen!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [smiling] What a whimsical old soul it is!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But exceeding kind and honest—at least to me—he knows no bounds to his good wishes for my welfare—which is all I can say in extenuation of his freedom now to you, madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O, the well-meaning good creature cannot easily offend me.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Have a care, dear madam, your condescension don't destroy the respect I should preserve—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Let me beg of you to forget those distant words, respect, and madam—our com∣pliments are over, (tho' with much difficulty) [smiling] let us now resume that innocent fa∣miliarity we were bred together in, and ever were delighted with—when we parted last, you was less ceremonious; then, instead of madam, you call'd me your Emily—nay more, your dear Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: That I still might without a crime! for sure there can be nothing dearer to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Then why this distance—this reserve?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: O Emily! think but of your con∣dition, your rank in life, and think of mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And shall that lay a restraint upon our lips?—must they be denied to express what our hearts will feel, forgetful of distinc∣tion?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What my heart feels they can't ex∣press—gratitude, love, admiration! all the most susceptible can feel, or eloquent describe, is there.—My dearest Emily, still I must call you so—why are you thus kind—thus conde∣scending!—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: In what?—'prithee, now, where is the mighty difference between us? is not your father in every respect (but the lowest of all considerations, riches) as good as mine? and wherein can I pretend to vie with thee, who art an abstract of both their virtues!—but we grow serious—besides, you have to dress, and see that odious Sealand, which this detains you from; so, 'till we meet at dinner, dear George, adieu!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Adieu, sweet Emily! lovely, en∣gaging, bewitching Emily! O that I were but rich enough to dare aspire to thee! never did I repine at want of fortune but on thy account, and when I find that the only bar to my success, I must repine; since, were I not the child of poverty and dependance, what might I not hope!—her partiality for me, I think, is evident—and my determination to conquer this ill-suited passion, she has, in one moment, utterly destroyed! [he stands musing]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I gave my father the slip nicely— and here he is yet—and alone too, that's charming! Now, who knows but I may have better luck than I had before [aside]—Pray, sir, is not my young lady here? [George does not observe her.] Hoity toity! why he's speech∣less again—may be he is always so when he wants to kiss a pretty girl—I wish Sir Thomas wou'd pop in his head, and cry (as he did just now) kiss her, boy! kiss her again! [aside.]— Sir! Sir!—pray is not madam Emily here?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: [Starting from his reverie.] Ha! Emily! what of Emily?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Nothing, sir,—only I thought she had been here—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, no—she has just left me—the happiest, yet most wretched, of mankind! [aside.]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P:
Not one kiss, by jingo! I could cry for madness! I suppose he's proud, and thinks himself too much above me—marry come up! and yet—he is a pretty gentleman, and if I was as rich as a jew I'd marry him directly.— Stay—let me consider—I have got a little money by me that my father knows nothing of, if I don't buy a lottery-ticket I'll be burnt!—and if I get the twenty-thousand-pound-prize, nay, if I am so unlucky as to get only the ten-thousand, I'll tell him my mind directly—and sure then he won't think himself above me! I've heard say, that in London the gentry—ay, even your lords and dukes, now and then marry poor girls that are pretty—like me, for
love—nay, (tho' I hardly know how to believe it) folks say, they'll sometimes take up with their own, ay, or other people's, kept-madams! and I am sure it wou'd not be a quarter so bad as that, for a parson's son to marry a clerk's daughter!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT II. Scene, Sir Thomas Richacre's Garden.—A Summer House in view.—Metre comes out of the Summer House, William meets him carrying a Chair.

SP.SPEAKER: WILLIAM.
SP.P: HERE, master Metre, here be another chair, and now it be all right, I believe —there be two for madam Emily and young master Goodman—two elbow-ones for Sir Thomas and his reverence, and this gilded da∣mask one you bid me fetch for my lord—but ecod, if I was his worship, I'd set upon it myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha!—well, put it into the summer-house with the rest, that's my good lad.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Never stir if I don't believe it be made of lead, it feels so plaguy heavy—thof I suppose I only think so 'cause I fetch'd it with an ill-will—for, to be sure, I did grudge my labour most confoundedly.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Why so, William? I never knew thee idle yet—Why so?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, because I don't like un—and it goes mortally again' the grain with me to do any thing for such a scape-grace—for, as the ould saving be—he is like the wind at east, good to neither man nor beast!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: For shame, William, for shame! you should not speak so disrespectfully of a noble∣man.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Nobleman! why I hope, master Metre, you don't think such a whiffling chap as Lord Sealand deserves to be called noble? I'll be judg'd by yourself now, if he be one crumb like his worship, or a quarter so noble, —thof he be no more but a knight-barrow-knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: I profess, William, I do not think this light young lord so deserving of his dig∣nity as our nobles in general are said to be; which maketh me most heartily wish he was more like his worship's honour than he is.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: More like un! I'll be shot an' he be a bit like un—no more than a crab-apple be like a golden-pippin! I wonder, for my part (nay, for that matter, so do the whole neighbourhood) why such a good gentleman as Sir Thomas, keeps company with him, and lets him come dangling here for ever a'ter young madam, like a tantony-pig?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P:
Why, thou knowest, William, his lordship hath a great estate adjoining to his worship's—and, although he hath it not in his will, I fear, to do much good, it is in his power to do a great deal of harm, therefore,
I conjecture, his worship holdeth it prudent to keep friends with him.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: More the pity, I say, master Metre, that what few good men there be in the world should be obligated to truckle to the bad—or that any one should have a good estate that has not a good heart likewise!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: William! thou art an honest righ∣teous lad, I verily believe; and, although it hath pleased heaven to place thee in so hum∣ble a station, the uprightness of thy heart would adorn the princes and the rulers of the land, more than their costly raiment, precious stones, purple and fine linen!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Thanks to your kind opinion, master Metre—I do hope I shall never prove no other∣wise.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: I am morally certain thou wilt not— hold forth thy hand—there is a shilling for thee—and I will bestow upon thee too a do∣nation of good books, particularly, the Old and New Testament, the Liturgy, with, thereunto annexed, the Old and New Version of the Psalms of David, done into English Metre.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: 'Thank you kindly—odsbobs, I shall be quite set up—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Moreover, I will recommend thee unto his reverence, to succeed me in my holy office upon my demise—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: What, me to be clerk and sexton! oh lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P:
To qualify thee for which important undertaking, I will instruct thee in every thing appertaining unto a clerkship—particularly in psalmody—likewise how to adapt, as well as
set, a stave—and eke also, both audibly and emphatically to cry Amen!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I shall soon learn, for I know all the notches already, and can give the key with the pitch-pipe, and sing fol fa with e'er a he in the parish—and as to Amen—no offence, master Metre, I hope—but I could say it twice as laudable as you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Audible, thou would'st say, William —and audibly did I use to say it—but, alack∣aday, I am waxen old, and my voice is im∣paired—but when I was thy age—hem! A—a—men!

DIV2.STAGE: Speaking as loud as he can, Wil∣liam puts his hand before Metre's mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Odsbobs! here comes my lady.

DIV2.STAGE: Emily enters—William carries the Chair into the Summer House—Metre is going, Emily recalls him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, not here!—where is my George? what can have become of him?—Mr. Metre!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Did your good ladyship please to call?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Are you going into the house, pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Unless your ladyship hath occasion to send me elsewhere.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, only be so good to tell Patty I want to speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: I will communicate your ladyship's pleasure unto her incontinently.—Ah! when young, I had a voice like any bell!—and, as the old song sayeth, could dig a grave, and set a stave, and say Amen full well! [aside as he goes off.]

DIV2.STAGE: Exit Metre.—William returns, and is following Metre, Emily calls him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: William!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ma'am!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Step to the cottage below our garden-door in the green-lane; I am told the poor labourer there is ill, and the family in great distress—give this to the poor woman— [gives money and be careful not to mention it to any body else, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: No, indeed, ma'am, I'll never open my lips about it, but when I'm praying heaven to bless and preserve your ladyship's goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Run then, William, as fast as you can; and go out at the garden-door, that none of our family may see you.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, I will—I'm sure I should not think this a heavy load if it weigh'd as much again as the gilt chair, for I should like to be so employ'd from one week's end to the other!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What a humane creature! such good∣ness must not go unrewarded.—How diffe∣rent are our natures! this uninstructed boy, possessing virtues too seldom met with in the most exalted!—What then avail a pompous title, wealth, and illustrious ancestry? since the meanest peasant, possessing but humanity, has no superior! while the heart that cannot feel for others' woes, disgraces, not only a distin∣guished rank, but even our very nature!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Did you want me, ma'am? my father said—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Yes, Patty; my papa intends passing the afternoon in the summer-house, so order coffee and tea to be served there.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Patty—have you seen any thing of young Mr. Goodman since dinner?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am, I saw him steal slily by the hall windows a little while ago—I don't know where he went, but I have a notion he has seen some trollop in the neighbourhood, as he came along in the post-chaise, that he has taken a liking to, and is gone in search of— and I'm sure that's a shame, when he might pick and choose out of the two prettiest in the whole county!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Why, Patty, this is love in downright earnest—I'll be whipt if you have not quite forgot poor William, and are jealous of this young gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Jealous! not I indeed, ma'am—Wil∣liam is worth a dozen of him—young gentle∣man! he don't behave like one, that's what he don't, for he has not once had the good manners to offer to salute me since he came home.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Poor Patty! that is provoking, in∣deed—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, ma'am—I believe you'd think it was, if he had serv'd you so!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed! ha, ha, ha! why I wish you are not jealous of me next.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P:
No, ma'am, I am pretty secure there, if I really did like him well enough to care about him—for, your ladyship being heiress to so many thousand pounds a year, he would
never dare to make love to you, ma'am—and I hope, ma'am, setting case you was weak enough to like the poor lad, you'd never demean yourself so much as to tell him so.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I don't know that, Patty; for setting case (as you phrase it) I lik'd him, I should make very little scruple of confessing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Indeed! lord, lord, how little pride some people have! If I was a baronet's daughter, I'd never think of taking up with a poor clergyman's son, when I might marry a lord, and be a countess.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: A mind like his would reflect a lustre upon the meanest origin! and I desire, Patty, you would restrain this freedom, nor make so free with Mr. Goodman's name again.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Dear heart, ma'am, I did but just speak—and I should not have said what I have, had not your ladyship ask'd me about him—if I am a little jealous of him, there's somebody to the full as jealous of me!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: How I am tormented with this silly girl, while my mind is rack'd with a thousand apprehensions! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: You wanted coffee and tea serv'd in the summer-house, I think you said, ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Yes, child! [peevishly.]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Child! goodlack!—ay—she is in love with him as sure as a gun, as well as myself—I'm sure I won't buy a lottery ticket since that's the case, for, 'twou'd be only throw∣ing my money away! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Heyday! what ails the foolish girl! I wish she is not jealous in good earnest—and —what's the matter with the other foolish
girl! I wish she is not more affected than she ought—for, were I certain George was absolutely gone upon the errand Patty men∣tioned, I believe—I should not be very well pleas'd!—but it cannot be—therefore be still, my heart! poor frighten'd fool! nor throb and flutter without cause!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ma'am, I ha'run as hard as ever I cou'd, and the poor souls send their duty and ten thousand thanks to your ladyship—but, blessed be providence, they say, they don't want any money now.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: How so, William?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, ma'am, what d'ye think? when I went into the cot, who should I see sitting by the sick man but young Master Goodman; and thof the poor soul be so bad, 'twould ha' puzzled a stranger to tell which of the two ail'd most, young gentleman look'd so piteously.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed! was young Mr. Goodman there?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, ma'am—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My mind's at rest again! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And the poor woman told me he had been there a good while, and had writ a description to be made up at 'pottecary's for her husband, and had guve 'em money to pay for it, and more to buy victuals with, and kiss'd the sweet babes, and was so kind to 'em, nothing could be like it!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: The dear, the amiable youth! how could I wrong him by my late ungenerous fears! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And when I came out, ma'am, who should I see but his worship and Dr. Goodman, and they ax'd me what I had been doing there, and what I was crying about— for, to be sure, young gentleman's goodness had made my eyes water a little—and when I told 'em, I wish I may never stir if their honours did not almost cry too!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And where did my papa and the doctor go, William?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why where do you think they went, ma'am?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Nay, how can I tell?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I am sure it made my heart dance with joy, to see such a grand gentleman as Sir Thomas Richacre, a knight-barrow-knight, justice of peace and quorum, stoop to go into a poor hovel like that—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What, the cottage you had just come out of!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Yes, indeed, ma'am—into poor Quickset's little hut!—but I cou'd not see Lord Sealand, thof I look'd all about—and if he had gone along with their honours, his coat wou'd not ha' set the worse on his back o' Sunday, as the saying be—axing your lady∣ship's pardon!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed, William, I am entirely of your mind—but, if I was not, why do you ask my pardon? it is not me you are speak∣ing against.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P:
Noa, madam, mercy forbid! it's out of any one's power to say ill of your lady∣ship—
but it be rife all over the parish that your ladyship's going to be married to my lord, and there's not a living soul but what pities you: for your ladyship's as much be∣lov'd as my lord's hated—and to be sure, that's not a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Well, William, I am not married to his lordship yet—and 'till I am, you need not fear offending me by such remarks.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Thank your ladyship's goodness— does your ladyship please to want any thing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, 'thank you, William, not at present.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: [aside as he is going] Now I know the poor souls don't want for any thing, if I can but coax Patty into a good humour, I shall be as happy as a king—Odrabbit it! I axe ten thousand pardons, but if I had not like to ha' forgot to remember to give your lady∣ship the piece of gold again, I'll be shot.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: William, you are a humane good lad, and shall not want encouragement—keep it yourself as an earnest of what I may do farther for you.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: 'Thank you kindly and heartily, ma'am!—it be more your goodness than my desert— [aside] now I'll run back again to the cottage t'other way, and watch 'till their honours be gone in at garden door, then make the poor souls have the money, whether they will or not!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Married to Lord Sealand! I shudder to hear it mentioned! whence could such a report take rise? from himself, or from Sir
Thomas? sure my dear father, kind to all be∣sides, will never single me out to be cruel to! and (as he does nothing without his worthy friend's advice) surely the good, the pious Doctor Goodman never can approve it! —why should I fear then?—and yet I do— the bare idea that it is possible makes me tremble—gracious heaven! how dreadful is my present situation! demanded by a worthless insolent I detest! hopeless of him I cannot chuse but love! Oh! George, where is the spot, or what the condition I should not think a paradise with thee, rather than share a king∣dom with Lord Sealand! [Lord Sealand sings without] Heavens! here comes the hateful wretch—let me endeavour to conceal my agi∣tation!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Emily, my divine creature! how could you be so cruel to leave me to mope and grow stupid for want of your animating brilliancy and vivacity? 'twas abolutely bar∣barous, carissima mia!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Those are qualities, my lord, I am not happy enough to possess—but surely 'tis impossible for Lord Sealand ever to be grave, whose animating brilliancy and vivacity would dispel the gloom of a Greenland winter.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: O you flatterer! but, perhaps, you really think so—do you, my adorâble? make me happy by confessing it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I dare say your lordship has not the least doubt but every body thinks so.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Mia bella Signora! I see you do—I read it in those eyes, whose brightness I adore more than the beacons on the South-foreland, when I am returning from Calais in a hazy evening.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Calais! bless me, does your lordship ever venture so far.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Far! O child, that's nothing to me who have even had thoughts of sailing up the Baltic, or crossing the Bay of Biscay, mere∣ly to kiss the empress's fair hand, and the pope's great toe! and for a kiss of those di∣vine lips, I would explore the North-East-Passage! nor think I flatter you, my angel, when I swear, that neither flip when I am aboard, or capillaire ashore, are half so dear to me!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: You do me great honour indeed, my lord—but does your lordship ever taste the li∣quor they call flip?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Taste it? ay, many a can do I toss off when I have my watch-coat and trow∣sers on, and am turning to windward in a brisk gale—but the flip I drink is not like the vile stuff commonly so call'd, for mine has a most delicate flavour, as I always mix it with capillaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Well, it is amazing to me what could induce a person of your lordship's delicacy to venture upon this dangerous amusement you have lately taken a fancy to.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P:
Why, faith, mia cara! I com∣menced sailor merely to avoid the imputation of effeminacy—tho' if we meet with any bad weather at sea, I immediately retire to my
cabin, and order my pilot, O'Connor, to make for land with all convenient speed.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! you are perfectly in the right upon my word, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: But let us change the coarse indelicate subject—I am almost tir'd of the scheme, and another sea-sickness will make me drop it, I believe—pray what's become of George? first he walk'd off—then you, mia crudel! deserted us—and soon after, Sir Tho∣mas ask'd me to go with him to see the sick fellow old Goodman was speaking of—as if I had been a physician—which I declining, he took away Domine, and left me to indulge in soliloquy, just as I was concluding our marriage, ma chere! upon honour I have not been treated so politely ever since I lodg'd with Mynheer Vander-Dunder, the fat Burgo-master at Rotterdam.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Concluding our marriage, did you say, my lord!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Si, Signora—we were on the very brink of settling the preliminaries.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Why, does your lordship really sup∣pose we are to be married?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Is it possible you can still make that a question? have not I told you repeatedly I would marry you, my angel?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: But did I ever consent to marry your lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Consent? egad I don't recollect I ever ask'd you—on purpose to spare your confusion in consenting, as I am sure my adorâble will. [taking her by the hand.]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Perhaps your lordship may be de∣ceiv'd!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What do I see! Emily and Lord Sealand hand in hand! distraction! now I am lost indeed!—but she seems averse to him— why then should I tamely give her up? what is his fortune, title, birth, to me? I have a mind as noble, name as fair, tho' unadorn'd with honours and possessions!—but I rave— and, if perceiv'd, shall be thought a mean list'ner to their converse. [retiring]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Ha! George! where have you been, you runaway! in some dull arbour I suppose, poring over your musty Greek.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I beg pardon, my lord, for this ac∣cidental intrusion—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: O you are come quite oppor∣tunely to help me soften the rigour of this obdurate fair one.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I shall be but an indifferent advo∣cate for love, my lord—it is a language I have not been used to talk.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Pho, pho, tell me something mon∣strous tender now out of your Ovid, Catullus, Tibullus, or any of the soft amorous dogs, suited to the extreme violence of my passion.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Were I in your place, my lord, I should rather follow their example, than barely repeat their words—they never said any thing to the object of their wishes but what was dictated and inspir'd by love itself!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P:
Ay, that's true—but a rough tar as I am, can't be suppos'd to have so many
fine expressions ready on these occasions, as you studying rhyming sonneteers; and Lady Sea∣land, like a tender mother, would never suffer me to read or study much, for fear of spoiling my eyes, or making my head ake—come, do now, say something monstrous clever for me— and, in the mean time, (as I fancy my dad, that is to be, is return'd by this) I shall go and make you happy, my angel, by concluding the treaty with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My lord!—be not so precipitate I intreat your lordship!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Scaland.
SP.P: He, I am sure, will be no less proud of the honour of having me for a son-in-law, than you, my charmer, are to have me for a husband—therefore, mia cara sposa! think what day will be most agreable to you for the celebration of our nuptials; but, for your own sake as well as mine, let me intreat you, not to delay our felicity too long!—Addio! (jusqu'au revoir) Addio! mia contessa carissima! fa, la, la, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Insolent reptile!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Now had I not a father more attentive to the happiness than grandeur of his child, I should be completely miserable!—Oh, Georgel do not think lightly of me for this declaration —I'd sooner beg with thee, than shine in all the splendor this wretch's utmost power could place me!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
Dearest Emily! think not of me— had providence design'd us for each other, my lot in life had been more suited to your birth —as it is, tho' I have presum'd to love, I never cherish'd hope—for, not even to gain
thee, Emily! would I abuse my honour'd pa∣tron's confidence! may you, sweet maid, but meet one more deserving, while I pray heaven to bless and to protect you!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Do not talk so—thee only can I love! to thee only will I ever give my hand—I am sure my father will never force me to marry Sealand, or any one, against my will—and perhaps some blessed moment may incline him to prefer my poor, but virtuous George!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No more, no more, sweet Emily! I cannot bear it!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Well! we'll drop the subject!—pray, did you see Sir Thomas just now where you have been?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Where I have been?—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Yes, at the cottage, down the lane— William told me all.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Did he?—but, 'tis no great matter, for the poor woman told me all too, when she return'd from the door, (whither William had taken her to deliver your benefaction)—and likewise, that Sir Thomas and my father were talking with him in the lane—whereon, sus∣pecting they were coming there, I quitted the cot immediately, and return'd another way un∣perceived by them.

DIV2.STAGE: Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, George, where hast been, lad? I have been seeking you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I was only— [hesitating]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
Come, come, never blush at a good action; that's a false shame, and almost as wrong as not to be asham'd of a bad one: I know
where you have been, and how employed.— Your charity is sterling, I am sure, without that too common alloy of ostentation—and so is your's, my dear good girl!—but, pray, have you seen nothing of my lord lately, Emily? I expected to have found him here, for when I ask'd him to go with me, he declin'd it, say∣ing he'd walk a turn or two in the garden with you till I return'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: He was here just now, papa, and after addressing me in a most insolent manner, saying he was sure both you, sir, and myself would be proud of his alliance, he left me (as he said) to conclude the treaty with you!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: He did, ha? O, come along, I'll conclude it presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Sir! I hope—dear sir, [to Dr. Good∣man] speak to my papa—for heaven's sake in∣tercede for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Don't alarm yourself, dear madam —Sir Thomas will do nothing contrary to your happiness or inclination, I am certain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What's the fool frighten'd at?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: You said, sir, you'd conclude this hateful treaty!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, ay, so I will—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then I am lost indeed! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Is it possible, sir! must your poor Emily be made a sacrifice!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Heyday! what the plague's the matter with the girl? I'll conclude it—put an end to it—break it off, you fool!—what can I say more to please you? I'd sooner marry you to William, or old Metre, than the first duke in the land, if he had no better a heart than Lord Sealand.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Then I am happy!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And I! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ma'am, Lord Sealand sent me to beg the favour of your ladyship to come and play a tune upon your harpsichord till Sir Thomas return'd—which (as you came in the garden way) his lordship did not know you was, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: A tune, eh?—ay, ay, we'll go play him a tune directly—I'll soon put you out of your pain, I warrant you—for when he hears what must be known before you marry any one, and what I believe I shall now tell him, I fancy he'll give over the chace of his own accord.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Heavens! what can that be? [aside to Emily]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: If he does not, you will perhaps think better of him than you do at present, and willingly be Lady Sealand.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Never, sir, I am certain!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well, well, there's no knowing— we shall see—go, children, go before us.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Come, my sweet Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What can my father mean? [aside to each other.]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I know not what to think, whether to with or dread an explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Nor I!—but (be it what it may) assure yourself, dear George, I never will be Lady Sealand!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I believe, my good old friend, no better time than now for the discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I think so too, dear sir—heaven prosper the event!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Shall she be Sealand's if he holds his purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: By no means, sir! and heaven avert, hereself should ever wish it!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, so say I—but to be a countess is perhaps an almost irresistable temptation!

DIV2.STAGE: Exeunt Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman. Patty remains.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: By gemini, I am in great hopes she'll have my lord! and if she does, I think I stand no bad chance of having young Mr. Goodman! oh, lud! the very thoughts of it make me al∣most out of my wits!—but, hang this college-education —he seems so very bashful, I am afraid he'll never have courage to ask one the question downright—what shall I do then?— why, I don't know any other way than this— if he can't get the better of his modesty, and ask me, I must e'en try if I can't conquer mine, and ask him!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ecod, here she be!—I've found the little baggage at last—why, Patty, love! I thought I'd lost you—never stir if I ha'n't look'd up and down for you like bewitch'd— odsbodikins! I'm glad I ha' found you.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: [coldly] Why, did you want any thing, William?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P:
Want any thing, Patty! no, not I —nothing but to see thee, cause you know you was a little frumpish afore dinner; and I 'a'n't
been easy in my mind ever since—come, Patty, won't you make it up?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Make what up, Mr. William? I don't know that we have had any difference— you have done nothing to offend me, and I have no reason to suppose I have said or done any thing to affront you.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Me! no, lord love your dear heart! I never was angry with you two minutes toge∣ther in my life—so let's kiss and friends—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Kiss!—Pray, Mr. William, keep your distance—I don't know what behaviour of mine can have caus'd you to forget yourself so much.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, Patty, you be only joking sure—come, gi' us a buss, you little cross-patch you.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Why, William, you have been drink∣ing sure, or you could never be so bold.

SP.SPEAKER: William,
SP.P: Drinking, Patty!—I don't know what you mean by such an insinivation as that —I believe (ay, and you knows it too as well as I do) there ben't a soberer lad in all the parish—drinking!—lord help me!—if I have swallow'd a drop or a crumb of any thing since breakfast, but one horn of ale, and a bit of meat as big as my three fingers, I'm a drunk∣ard and a glutton into the bargain! and I'd as lief be thought a thief as either—so you shou'd not say that of me, Patty!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Bless me, Mr. William, I said nothing about your eating—it's nothing to me what you eat, or drink either—what do you think I care? or whether you ever eat or drink again or not!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Indeed!—if I thought you was in earnest, Patty, I don't think I ever should!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Well, that's none of my business, you know—I don't concern myself about inferior servants!—all I desire of you is, that you will not make so free with me for the future as you have had the confidence to do lately, for I am determin'd I won't put up with it!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, I am sure you can't say I ever behav'd uncivil to you, Patty—and if so be I have made bold to tell you I lov'd you, I said nought but truth—ay, and you have said as much to me more than once, for all you're so scornful now.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I say I lov'd you? no, William!—I own I had a sort of friendship for you, because I thought you an honest young man and so forth—but, love? O, no, William! I am very sorry you mistook my civility—I never had such a thought I assure you—I have very different views!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Patty!—eh?—what do you say?— don't you go to—dear Patty!—odrabbit it! my heart's so full I can't speak to her—and, if I could help it, I'd never speak to her again!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I should be very glad of it—and I desire, nay, I insist upon it, that you never offer to open your lips to me again; for if you do I sha'n't answer you, and so, your ser∣vant!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Stay, Patty—one word more before we break off our courtship—for a courtship it has been, say what you will—ay, and a tender one too! or else when I set off for Oxford so long ago with Master George—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: George! you make very free with your betters methinks—it might be Mr. Good∣man in your mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ay, bless his dear soul! there's no name too kind for him—but, as I was going to say—if so be you was not in love with me, as well as I in love with you, why did you break this bit of gold with me, which I have worn next my heart ever since? but I'll be hang'd if I wear it any longer—come off, rot thee!—there, there's your keep-sake, your love-token again! and you're a false-hearted girl!— and if you'll promise never to speak to me again, I never will to you while I have breath in my body!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I believe there's no great need of pro∣mising on my side, I shan't be the first to break the silence, I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why then fare thee well, Patty! my heart's my own again!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ay, and a good riddance! take up with a footman indeed, when I have such a prospect of being a gentlewoman—I wonder who'd be fool then! I'm sure I won't be such a one, and so your servant, Mr. William!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And your servant, Mrs. Patt! if you go to that—a murrain take her for a scorn∣ful young toad! [bawls after her] I don't care a brass thimble for you! no nor a pin's point! —and you're a base, deceitful, false-hearted— [bursts out a crying] odrabbit it! I don't think I shall get the better of this the longest day I have to live!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT III. Scene, the Summer-house.—Lord Sealand, Sir Tho∣mas Richacre, Doctor Goodman, George, and Emily, discovered seated.

SP.SPEAKER: LORD SEALAND.
SP.P: AND now the decks are clear'd of the tea equipage, if you please, Sir Thomas, we'll resume our topic.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: With all my heart, my lord; the sooner we come to the point the better.

SP.SPEAKER: George,
SP.P: [rising] You have some private busi∣ness with his lordship, I believe, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: O no, there are no secrets going forward, George; at least, none that are to re∣main so—you need not stir, boy.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: With your leave, sir, I'll take a turn or two in the garden the while— [aside] I dread the event, nor dare I stay to hear it— heaven preserve you, my dear—lost Emily!

SP.SPEAKER: Lord Sealand.
SP.P: Now, sir, if you please—for I wait with as much impatience as a becalm'd vessel for a brisk gale to drive her safe into port.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: A brisk gale quotha! ecod, I have a notion there will blow such a breeze pre∣sently as will go near to overset you, my lord —or that your vessel, not being heart of oak, will spring a leak; for our discourse will take a turn you little think of.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Dear papa, permit me to retire! [rising]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: By no means, my dear—there is a particular reason why you should be present, otherwise indeed it might be deem'd a solecism in forms—but, don't be alarm'd, for I have not the most distant idea that this will come to any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: What a savage!—O, sir, we'll dispense with a little form—to the point, if you please, Lady Sealand and I are all atten∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [aside] Insolent and cruel!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: To begin then—your lordship hath address'd this young woman?—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: This angel! this goddess whom I adore!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Plain English, if you please, my lord—and demanded her of me in marriage? —pray now, if I may be so bold, what is your lordship's motive for it?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: What can it be but the most ar∣dent passon?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: For her?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: For her! who else, dear sir, could I possibly—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Say rather, what else?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I don't understand you, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, your lordship being (no doubt) pretty well inform'd of the value of my rent-roll; is that, or this [taking Emily by the hand] the goddess you adore?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: This is mighty strange, Sir Tho∣mas—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
No offence I hope, my lord— but, as I must be assur'd that whoever marries her has no other motive than a real, a disin∣terested affection for herself; this is the single
question, upon your answer to which depends the event.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Propose it, dear sir, propose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: If, instead of being daughter to a baronet, and heiress to a very considerable estate, she had no other recommendation or endow∣ment than her own beauty and virtue, would you, my lord, or would you not, raise her to the rank of Lady Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Is it possible, sir, you can have a doubt of it? what is the condition I wou'd not raise her from!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Emily, my dear, come hither—I am going to lose thee, my little cherub!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Sir! is it possible!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: The time is come, sweet child, I must resign thee!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [to Dr. Goodman] Good sir, support me—I cannot—oh! [faints]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: [to Sir Thomas] Dear sir, her spirits are quite overcome—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, gentlemen;— nothing but the mauvaise honte usual on these occasions—or perhaps the excess of joy may have been too powerful for her—where the devil is my eau-de-luce?—look up, carissima mia sposa!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [reviving] O my dear father!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: One kiss, sweet girl! and I resign that name—for, I am not your father!—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Gracious heaven!—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: What do you say, Sir Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I am not her father—and now, my lord, determine—here she is, as rich in personal and mental gifts, as she is poor in fortune, for she has none!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: The devil! what a narrow escape! I had like to have weigh'd anchor, and hoisted sale for that damn'd long round-the-world-voy-age of matrimony, in a vessel without either ballast or provision! [aside]—Why, undoubt∣edly, Sir Thomas, fortune was my least consi∣deration—but, if the young lady is not your daughter, 'tis proper I should first know who is her father—it may be somebody whose fa∣mily it would be improper for me to marry into.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [kneeling to Sir Thomas] Most honour'd sir!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Rise, rise, my dear! you must kneel no more to me! [raising her]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Where shall I kneel? where seek my father, if you are not!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Turn hither, my heart's darling! and behold him—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Did I hear right? are you, sir, are you my father!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I am! I am! [embracing her] I have endur'd a long constraint, but at length am free to boast—I am your father!—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Heyday! here's a turn! the wind has chop'd about with a vengeance—one mi∣nute south, and the next due north as ever it can blow.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [to Sir Thom.] O sir, forgive me, nor think this an ill return for your paternal good∣ness.—I love—I honour you most highly, sir, and ever must revere you! but nature pleads most strongly in my breast—I love my father too! [kneeling to Dr. Goodman, who raises and em∣braces her]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why that's my brave girl! I never yet knew half your goodness, and love you (if possible) better now than ever.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Well, upon honour, this is the most whimsical adventure I ever met with— what, in the name of oddity, Sir Thomas, could induce you to bring up the young gentlewoman as your's?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: That's my concern, my lord—I had my reasons for it, which time perhaps may shew—the only question necessary at present is, whether (if she is willing) you will, or will not, marry her?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: A moment's pause, I beg, Sir Thomas—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Pho, pho, come—speak boldly, man—was it the girl, or the estate you ador'd? in plain english, are you a man of honour, or are you a—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Sir Thomas—you are really so precipitate—I beg the indulgence of a few moments reflection—I'll—think a little, ma∣dam, and let you know my determination pre∣sently—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My lord, you need not trouble your∣self to think about it; for rest assur'd, that (fall'n as you may think me) nothing can in∣duce me ever to be your lordship's!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: [aside] I never met with such a cursed embarras before!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! so much for modern love!—Emily, you have lost your countess∣ship, my dear—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: His refusal has made me happy, sir, beyond expression—and so I flatter myself it will make George—ha!—George!—mer∣ciful heaven! the thought occur'd not 'till this moment—he is my brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And I fancy you had conceiv'd more than a sisterly affection for him—eh, Emily?—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I had indeed, sir! for, to confess what now is needless to conceal, I lov'd him ar∣dently; and (ignorant of my birth) had I been mistress of the world, he must have shar'd it with me, or I had been a beggar!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, I thought as much—well, well, time's a good physician, and cures more ills than half the doctors living—it will wear off, I warrant you—no sign of my lord wea∣thercock's turning about again? no!—I be∣lieve it's in vain to expect him—we had better seek for George, and inform him of what has pass'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Come, my delight! my only pride! my sweet child, come—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Excuse me a little, my dear father! I'll follow you directly—I will but dry thes tears and—oh! [in a burst of grief.]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Pho, pho, never take on so about it, Emily—you sha'n't go without a husband yet, if there's one in the kingdom that deserves you—what say you to a Richacre, my girl?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
Oh, sir, that I respect, revere and love you with a most filial affection, I think you do not boubt—but—most honour'd sir! my other parent!—let me stop there—my heart's too
full!—be not offended, sir—I can no more— Oh, George! George!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well, well, we'll talk no more about it at present—but upon my word you must not remain single, Emily—for, to tell you the truth, I should have been sadly baulk'd, and my whole scheme frustrated, had my lord behav'd otherwise; as I have all along had hopes (which I flatter myself will yet be ac∣complish'd) of prevailing on you to accept for ever that name you have so long honour'd by the using!—come along, my old friend— friend, quotha! ecod, who knows how nearly we may be related soon! eh?—ha, ha, ha!

DIV2.STAGE: Exit Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What a reverse of fate! how am I bereft of all my fond, vain hopes of happiness and love!—had I been reduc'd to the most abject poverty—had I lost him I thought my father, and found no other—had every calamity our woe-fill'd lives are fraught with, but this, at once besel me, I had still been happy; but now, (oh, George! oh, brother!) I am sunk ten thousand times more deep than wretch e'er plung'd before!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Alone, Emily? where are Sir Tho∣mas and my father? I saw my lord go down the yew-tree walk, so thinking the conference over, I return'd to learn how it had ended— what was th' important secret on which so much depended?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Oh, George!—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: How! weeping! then I know enough, and now am nothing! O fortune! title! how powerful are your charms that can betray goodness itself and make it err!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily,
SP.P: Forbear, forbear!—you know not why I grieve—you can't conceive the exquisite distress of my present situation!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Not conceive how dreadful to be given to those we hate, as I am persuaded you do Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Oh, George, there now needs no dis∣guise—the doom irrevocable's past! did you indeed e'er love me?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Love you! do I breathe? do I ex∣ist?—could I, but to love you!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Then we both are truly wretched!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: We are indeed! but if, as I have fondly thought, our love was mutual, how doubly wretched is your fate—doom'd thus to marry one that you detest!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, that's not my grief—'thank hea∣ven he has refus'd me.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Refus'd you!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: You will not wonder when I can tell you why—Sir Thomas Richacre—is—not my father! [bursting into tears]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Not your father! amazing—yet most happy sound! then I may hope—and the first gleam I ever knew now shoots into my soul!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, there is no hope—an eternal barrier is fix'd between us! for you are—I cannot speak it!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I am—gracious heaven!—what?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My brother!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Your brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My dear, dear brother!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Support me, or I fall!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: With my very life! [weeping and em∣bracing him]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: So, so! here's fine work going for∣ward—kissing and hugging at a rare rate! it's more than he ever offer'd to me!—by jingo, I don't half like this; she'll never have my lord, nor I him, if they go on thus—it's well I did not buy the lottery-ticket, seeing how matters are going! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Look up, dear George!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Dear George! lord, how loving we are! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Am I indeed so near to you?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, you can't be much nearer, I think! in her very arms! how near wou'd you be, I wonder! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Your brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: What! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then there is no hope indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No, I hope not—but, what can this mean? [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Patty!—how long have you been here?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I am but this moment come, madam —Sir Thomas sent me to desire your lady∣ship—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O Patty, you must forget those words —I am no lady now—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No ma'am! how so?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
No longer heiress to a splendid for∣tune, but sister to this much lov'd youth—the
virtues of a reverend parent must be now our joint inheritance!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But to what purpose, Emily, was you bred up as daughter to Sir Thomas?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: He told Lord Sealand there was a reason for it, which time perhaps would shew— and, in addition to my misery, after my lord had left us, said he was pleas'd at his refusal of me; having all along intended I should still keep the name of Richacre—meaning, no doubt, with my concurrence, to marry me himself!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Astonishing! yet that accounts for all.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Good gracious! I hardly know how to believe all this—I am afraid she's only jok∣ing [aside]—lord, ma'am, I hope you an't serious all this time—are n't you Sir Thomas's daughter indeed?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: No, Patty, you have lost your mistress.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: [aside] I have found a husband in the stead tho', and that's ten times better!—but I must seem sorry—Dear heart, ma'am, I am vastly concern'd to hear this, for you was very good to me, and I must never expect to have so many nice cloaths given me again, un∣less his worship should really be so kind as to marry you himself, ma'am.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Happy, happy girl! 'would I had no greater grief than thine!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P:
Why, to be sure, ma'am, the black ox has trod upon your foot a little, as the say∣ing is—and one misfortune seldom comes alone, as the other saying is—you have been very unlucky indeed, ma'am, to lose a great fortune,
and your sweetheart too, both at once—for I do verily believe you had a kindness for Mr. Goodman before you knew he was your bro∣ther—but now that's all over.— [aside] 'Thank my kind stars! and I shall be Mrs. Goodman as sure as fate!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, Patty, it is not all over!—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Nor will be but with life!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Lord, ma'am! why sure you wou'd not love your own brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Not love him! who shall debar me that?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Nay, ma'am, I only just spoke—for brothers and sisters did formerly marry I grant, or the world could not have been peopled— but that's quite out of fashion now, you know, ma'am—unless indeed you had been roman∣catholic-papishes, and were lucky enough to be Sir Thomas's children instead of Dr. Good∣man's; because I have heard say, if people have but money enough, the pope will grant a —compensation—I think they call it, or some such hard name, (I suppose it means an act of parliament) for a man to marry his own grand∣mother! but indeed, ma'am, if I was you, I'd think no more of my brother, but take Sir Thomas at his word, and marry my father— that is, as he is not your father.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Prithee have done, Patty; I am not yet reconcil'd enough unto my fate, to bear this ill-tim'd mirth—I might, nay, perhaps I shall, find refuge in a cloyster, and dedicate my future wretched life to heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
No, Emily! 'tis I should be seques∣tered from the world; you have been taught to look for happiness, and, by accepting of Sir
Thomas's most worthy hand and noble fortune, yet may find it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Impossible! oh, name it not again— never will I basely take the hand and fortune I cannot in return for give my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Forgive me, dearest maid! nor think I had any view in what I said, but your repose and welfare; for what little patrimony my honour'd father may have gather'd for us both, shall now be wholly yours; as I will immedi∣ately enter into holy orders, devote my life to a religious celibacy, nor ever think again of love or womankind!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: O goodness heart! that will be a great pity, sir; for there's many a pretty girl, I dare say, would be proud to have you.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Come, my dear brother! let us attend Sir Thomas and our father, I promis'd to fol∣low them directly.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Our father! oh, Emily—my sister! —I cannot bear the thought—it shocks—it overpow'rs—it mads me!—my sweet Emily —go you, while I endeavour to compose this agitation of my spirits before I see them.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: May heaven restore you to your peace of mind!—but mine—is lost for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: [after some little pause] Sir,—sir,—sir!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: What do you say, child? [peevishly]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P:
Why, sir,—I hope you won't be angry at such a simple girl as me offering to advise you—but really I would not have you think of living single; for to my certain knowledge, there is a girl in the world, ay, and a good
pretty girl too, that's not far off, would be very sorry you shou'd die a batchelor.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Which I most surely shall! [sighing]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
