SP.P: Mercy forbid, sir!—for indeed you are a very pretty gentleman! and seeing as how you and your sister can't conveniently come together, if I was in your place, I shou'd look about me a little—and if such a thing was to happen, that you even took a fancy to me, sir, I don't think I could find in my heart to be cruel to you—and tho' I am not your equals, you might go farther and fare worse— for I have a little money by me, and a pros∣pect of getting a very large sum soon—and you know, sir, I am a sort of an heiress (as I may call it) besides, and I dare say my father has sav'd something worth having. [she stands curt∣sying and simpering to him]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: How this silly girl torments me! I had better check her, or the giddy creature may suppose I know not what—I thank you, Patty, for your good will to me,—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Thank you, Patty! O gemini, I be∣lieve he'll come to at last. [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But hope you'll not deceive yourself into what might hereafter prove a trouble to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No indeed, sir, it never would—so far from it, every thing I did for you wou'd be a pleasure to me!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Still you mistake me, my good girl—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Good girl! O the dear soul, I shall have him as sure as a gun! [aside] No, in∣deed, sir, I don't—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Pray hear me without interruption—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Yes, sir, that I will [curtsying] for, to be sure, I cou'd hear you talk for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I am afraid you have conceiv'd some∣thing like love for me—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Like love? indeed, sir, if a poor bash∣ful girl must speak out—it's love in downright earnest! [curtsying very low]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Pray don't interrupt me—you have entertain'd, I say, a partiality for me you mis∣take for love, and which a return to might pos∣sibly confirm in you; but, as that can never be, I intreat you, for your own repose, in time to check it, and never think again of what is im∣possible!—Oh, love! thou tyrant o'er the heart, how contradictory are thy decrees!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Impossible! why is it impossible? sure I am not his fister too—lord, lord! that any body should stand so in their own light!— well—it don't signify fretting about it—if I can't have him, I must have somebody else?— and, as he won't marry me, I think I'll e'en behave kinder to poor William, for I'm sure he loves me dearly—and if I can but coax him to forget how I used him to day, and ask me the question (as he often has before) again, if I don't have him, I'll be whipt!—as I live, here he comes, and a likely lad he is as any in the parish—George Goodman, with all his airs, an't half so handsome.—I'll pretend not to see him, to try if he'll break his resolution and speak first.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ay, there she stands, a sulky thing! what can have made the little puss so plaguy cross-grain'd to day?—she won't take a bit of notice of me—a stubborn young baggage! and I'll be hang'd if I speak to her first—if I can help it! [seemingly going]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Not one word, by jingo!—if I don't take care I shall lose him too—since he won't speak, I must! so, come down proud stomach! —William!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Did you call, Mrs. Patty?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ay, William,—why you pass by a body as if you had never seen one before.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, Mrs. Patty, I be unwilling to anger any one—and the last time we parted, you know you bid me never speak to you again; so I was trying to please you that way —thof it almost breaks my heart! but if it kill'd me outright, I shou'd not care, if it did but pleasure you, Patty! [half crying]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Lord, William! why you did not think I was in right earnest, did you?— ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Eh!—he, he, he! why, wa'n't you Patty? [wiping his eyes while he laughs]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Wa'n't I! why no, I tell you—I only did it to try you a little—ha, ha, ha!—that was all.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Was that all? lord, lord, if I cou'd not ha'sworn you was in downright earnest! for you have look'd all day long as if you cou'd eat me with a grain of salt!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: But I cou'd not tho', William—for I have too great a regard for you to hurt a hair of your head.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Have you indeed?—well now, that is kind to tell it me!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I should be very ungrateful to behave otherwise than kind to you, William, who have always profest so much love to me—nay, more than once even ask'd me to marry you.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ay, more than twenty times, Patty —and, if you were but willing, I'd axe your father leave to get Mr. Liturgy, our curate, to publish the banns for us next sabbath; and, as soon as ever we were out-ax'd, I'd marry you, and love you to my dying day!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I thank you kindly, William, for your offer—but, had not we better wait a few years longer, 'till we have sav'd a little to be∣gin the world with; as I don't imagine you are much richer than myself.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Pho, never heed riches, Patty— it's none but those who have too much already, that marry for the lucre of gain!—not that I be poor neither—last wages, I gave my father to save for me, made (with what he had before of mine) forty-four pounds, twelve shillings and fix-pence—that is, in even money, forty-two golden guineas and a half—so, you see, Patty, I be somebody, and ha' gotten a good round sum to begin the world—but, if we had not a sixpenny-piece between us, a young cou∣ple that have health and limbs to work, a good heart, and a sound conscience, have enough to begin twenty worlds!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P:
That's very true, William—and I don't think there's a heartier young couple in
the county than we are—besides, I have a very handsome sum of money by me too, and a power of good cloaths Miss Emily gave me—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Well then, Patty, shall us put what little we have together, and make a match on't, eh?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Indeed, William, I don't know what to say to it—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Come, never be faint-hearted—nor stand shilly-shally about it, you simple tony— [kissing her]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Bless my eyesight! what do I see? I hope the boy hath no unchaste purpose!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: You know, Patty, I do love you dearly—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: But honestly I trust—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And if you'll only say the word—

SP.SPEAKER: Meltre.
SP.P: Goodlack, I am terrified!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I'll go buy a ring directly.—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Oh!—I am satisfied!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I do know the size of this dear finger to a tittle—and it shall be as heavy as your heart can wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No, heavy rings are not the fashion now—let it be a light one, Willy.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Now then, my dear Patt, you be my own for ever and ever! [kissing and hugging her]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: He, he, he! their amorous parley is wond'rous pretty, I do protest!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Well, I vow, Billy, you have a most bewitching tongue, and have quite won my heart!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: He, he! that's pure!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: But you must ask my father's leave, for I would not do such a thing without his blessing for ever so much.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Thou art a dutiful good child, and heaven I hope will bless and prosper you! [still aside]

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why you know, Patty, I mention'd that before, and I'll go directly and tell un the whole story—odsflesh! here he is, as sure as a gun!—well, how lucky this be!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Heyday! what hath exhilarated thee so, William?—thou lookest as merry and happy!—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Merry and happy! ay, that I be— and hilarated too, as you call it, I believe; for, ecod! I hardly know whether I stand upon my head or my heels!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Why?—what hath pleased thee so overmuch?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: What I do hope will not displease you, or we shall be all in a sad quandary.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Lord, I am so asham'd, I can't look my father in the face. [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: What is all this about?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Why, fir,—I—that is, Patty and I, if—you—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Patty, and I, if—you! what? what? —why dost not speak out?—dost thou know, Martha, what it is he lacketh?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: I believe, father, I partly guess—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Well, what is it?—

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Why don't you tell my father, Mr. William?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: No, do you, Patty— [shifting each other to Metre]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Come, come, speak out boldly, lad! —faint heart never won fair lady.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Ecod, you've hit it! for—you must know, sir,—Patty being in love with me— that is—I being in love with she I mean—if so be you were but willing, we shou'd be main proud to become man and wife together!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Is this true, Martha?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: If you please, father! [blushing and curtsying]

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Yes, if you please, fa her! [bowing]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Why, William, as I have often told thee before, I believe thou art a very honest good lad—but, in troth, ye are both full young.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No indeed we a'n't, father!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: 'Twould be only losing time to stay any longer—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Well, I will take it into serious co∣gitation—as you will be under my eye—I think—I shall not oppose your virtuous incli∣nations, but will most humbly solicit the sanc∣tion and permission of his reverence and Sir Thomas, which I am prone to think, at my intreaty, will not be withheld.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: No, I hope not!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And then, father, when I am Patty's spouse, I'll keep the bible you said to day you'd give me as choice as old gold, to write the names of all our children in; if so be that we increase and multiply, which I do hope and pray to heaven we may, Patty!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Ay, and so do I, I am sure, William!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: [taking one of them in each hand] Never did I unto any prayer more fervently ejaculate Amen!
All three go off repeating—Amen!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT IV. Scene, a retired Part of the Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: EMILY.
SP.P: WHY do you persist, my lord, in detain∣ing me thus rudely, and prevent my returning to the house? pray let me pass, my lord—I desire you'd leave me!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Leave you? impossible, my an∣gelic creature! I exist but in your presence!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: That your lordship's existence has no sort of dependance upon me, I have had a most convincing proof.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: How can you be so cruel, my adorable! have I not declared the most ardent passion for you? am I not now confirming it? what can I say or you desire more?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indeed, my lord, I never thought to hear such words as these from you again—the effect Sir Thomas's explanation had upon your lordship, made me conclude—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: O, crudel! can you suppose I love you more or less, my charmer, for being daughter to this gentleman or that? no—my love is (as Sir Thomas wish'd it) intirely per∣sonal, and in possessing you, my angel, I ask no more!—bravo, Sealand! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: How have I been deceived! I blush to think how much I have wrong'd this gene∣rous man! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Why do you turn away, ma chére? why avoid me? sure I deserve a better treatment—I, that am waiting to receive, and place you in a state of affluence superior to that in which you have been bred, and from which you are so unexpectedly fall'n—but grieve not at that, for in my arms you'll find safe harbour from all the storms of fortune!— Pretty and poetical that! I don't think Ovid, or any of the love-sick tribe, ever said a better thing. [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O my lord! pardon me, I beseech you, for having thought of you so unworthily —I feel the warmest gratitude for this so gene∣rous a declaration, but cannot profit by it.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Say not so, my charmer—you know not half the good that waits on you and yours—your father shall be rais'd as high as I have power or interest to advance him—your brother too—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ah, my poor George!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: He shall be poor no longer— I'll give him a living, buy him a commission —or place him to his wish in whatever stile of life he may prefer—say but you will be mine—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What is there else I wou'd not do to serve my father and too-much-lov'd brother! and testify my gratitude, and the great respect I now have for your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P:
No more, no more; prithee, my charming angel, have done with gratitude, respect, and all such cold unanimated expres∣sions—love is all I require; give me but that, and all the joys and luxuries of life attend
you—well said again, Sealand! egad, this love makes a man talk divinely! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Oh, sir! think not of a wretched creature, who ne'er can taste of joy again!— were you, if possible, more noble, good and ge∣nerous than I now find you—were you at once the greatest and the best of human kind—so indelible is the impression (tho' ever unattain∣able the object it is made by!) on my afflicted heart, I could not marry with your lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Ha? what!—marry? O no, my dear, I did not mean that!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My lord!—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I love you, my divine creature, to adoration, almost distraction—every thing but matrimony—and that, oh, that wou'd be downright madness indeed! non, non, mia cara signora! that's quite out of the question now —your planks are started! and, from a vessel of burthen richly freighted, that has lost her cargo in a storm, you must now be cut down to a pleasure-boat!—no had metaphor that for a sailor—'gad, I think I shine to day! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Good heaven! what can your lord∣ship mean?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Mean, my charmer? mean that I adore you!—that you shall be as happy as love and gold can make you—shall command my heart and share my fortune—any thing but marriage; and that your own good sense must tell you is now impossible!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: At length I awake—my dream of ho∣nour, generosity, respect, and gratitude is now no more—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand,
SP.P:
But when your father and George are inform'd of what I propose for their ad∣vancement,
as well as for your own, I am sure they will readily—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Stop your licentious tongue, aban∣don'd wretch! are you not content with this most base attempt on me, but must my pious father and most virtuous brother be your sa∣crifices too! must they partake and countenance such guilt! oh, shame, shame! disgrace and scandal to your dignity and birth!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Heyday! what is all this? you can't be serious sure, child, in rejecting so gen∣teel an offer?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Sweet heaven look down with pity on me! the measure of my woes was full be∣fore—now it o'erflows!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Why, my dear, you have really made a very fine progress in the small time you have known yourself to be the parson's daughter —you both preach and pray most divinely upon my soul!—but we'll leave such dull stuff at present to those who know no better how to employ themselves—come, my Venus! let us retire to yonder mossy couch; where Paphian, Cyprian, and Citherêan boughs entwine to form a shade for love!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Unhand me, sir!—how do you dare insult me thus!—be assur'd, altho' Sir Tho∣mas is not my father, he will resent this out∣rage.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: O fie! how can you be so ill∣bred, my dear creature, and want so much courting to your own happiness? Come—I am certain you'll not be angry at a little gentle violence—let me thus force my angel to be kind!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: For honour's sake, my lord, forbear! pity my distress'd condition, bereft of fortune, love, almost of life! nor with unmanly violence add infamy to my already insupportable af∣flictions!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: 'Tis all in vain—you are a charm∣ing girl, I love you, the place is bien com∣mode! and—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: On my knees I beg!—think what distraction a reverend parent and a tender bro∣ther both must feel for my undoing! and, with a nobleness suited to your birth, my lord! forego the advantage you now have o'er my defenceless situation, and quit your horrid purpose!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Ridiculous! to suppose I'd miss this golden opportunity—no, no!—comply therefore, my charmer! and spare me the dis∣agreeable necessity of compelling you—you won't, eh? why then we must have a fair trial of who is strongest—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Help, help, sweet heaven! rescue a helpless creature from destruction! oh, save me from dishonour and perdition!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: You may as well be silent, child, for we are far enough from the house—nobody hears you—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Yes, villain, I do!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: And so has heaven!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Pox take him! is he here?—I wish he was at Oxford again with all my soul. [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O my dear brother! my protector! my guardian angel!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: My sister! my sweet innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: O rot you both! I have got into a blessed scrape here—I wish I was in the Bay of Biscay with all my heart! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Cruel insulter! to trample on a wretch just fall'n to earth!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: How did you dare, sir—if you had no other sense of guilt—how did you dare to violate the laws of hospitality thus grossly!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Oh, now you are going to preach —very good—proceed, sir—I am all attention! and must edify, no doubt, as I shall be finely lectur'd (I suppose) between you.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Insensible villain! dead to every feeling of shame, remorse, of honour or huma∣nity!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Sir, your most obedient!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: But, my lord! tho' you did not think this poor girl worthy to be your wife, remem∣ber she is my sister, and not to be dishonour'd by the most exalted ruffian!—for your pre∣sent safety be thankful we are unarm'd; else, in the cause of injur'd virtue, I should forget there was a female present, and punish your atrocious villainy on the spot!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Why really, sir, if you are cer∣tain of victory before the encounter, I think it full as well indeed that we are unarm'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: My dear George, contain yourself— oh!—I can scarce stand—pray lead me in!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Lean on me, my sweet sister, and fear nothing! have a care, sir, how we meet again, it may be fatal to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Be calm, my brother! my deliverer!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Fear nothing, dearest!—bear up— bear up! he must be more than man who in∣jures you while I am by, and less than man who could at any time attempt it! [looking scornfully on L. Sealand]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Pox take you for an ignorant, impertinent, meddlesome puppy, I say!—here am I to lose a fine girl, because her stupid bro∣ther knows so little of the world—rot him!— but I'll not drop the affair here I am deter∣mined—let me consider—um!—ay faith, the very thing! then she may squall 'till she's hoarse again, and I need not apprehend a second interruption—my French scoundrel shall about it instantly. [going]—Hold—what noise is that?—

DIV2.STAGE: [La Poudre and Robert cross the back of the stage, talking and laughing.]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Apropos! yonder is the very fel∣low I want—La Poudre! La Poudre!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Est ce que your lorship plese to vant a me?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Yes, I do please to vant a you, you puppy; come hither—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Je suis bien aise—I ver much glad den I happen to valk a dis vay—save a your lorship de peine to send for me.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Hold your damn'd Babel of a tongue, and mind what I say.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: I am not say von vard, mi lor— I am dumb.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I wish you was with all my soul—at least for the present—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Fort bien, my lor—I shall not open my mous—je ne dirai pas un mot—not von vard I vil speak.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Then cease that confusion of lan∣guages, you damn'd French chattering rascal, and hear me!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: I hear a your lorship parfaitement bien, and so may de whole parishe, ma foi!— you talk a so loud, I hear you if I was two tree mile off—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Ha! egad the puppy says true— and that's not altogether so proper at present— who was that with you?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Your lorship coashaman, Robert.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: That's lucky, by Jupiter! call the surly savage hither.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: I vil, my lor—ici!—Robert! Robert!—come speak a mi lor—courez, cou∣rez, plus vite! for vy you not make a great haste, you surly sauvage!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Do you want me, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Yes, Robert; put the horses to directly.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I can't just yet a while, my lord; the poor things have not quite din'd.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I tell you they must be put to directly—I have not a moment to spare.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Very well, my lord—then they shall only just finish the handful of meat that's in the manger—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Damn the manger! I tell you I must go immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: What, mayn't they make an end of the mouthful they're about, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I tell you no! I'll make an end of you, you rascal, if you don't get the carriage ready this instant.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Very well, my lord!—then I'll get 'em rubb'd down and put to presently—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Rubb'd down! you damn'd pro∣voking dilatory rascal, if they're not put to this moment, I'll down with a witness!

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: I wonder no'd wish to be a coach∣horse? poor souls I can never have a meal in comfort! [going towards the house]

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: But hark ye, Robert! go this way, or you'll ruin all—thro' the private door, which you may unbolt, at the bottom of this walk—if any of Sir Thomas's people are at the stables, make some pretence to get them out of the way—let nobody see you take the carriage out, be sure, if you can possibly avoid it, then saddle La Poudre's horse, and wait for us at that garden-gate.

SP.SPEAKER: Robert.
SP.P: Very well, my lord.—what maggot's in his head now, I wonder! not that I car'd a whisp of hay what was going forward, if the poor beastes had but fill'd their bellies—it's bad enough of all conscience to be a coach-man, but, damn it, it's worse yet to be a coach-horse.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Diable! for vy is all dis, mi lor?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Why, I have got into a cursed dilemma here, La Poudre, and you must be a damn'd rascal to endeavour to help me out of it.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Sans doute, my lord!—assuré∣ment I sal do every ting in my possibilité— mais vat dilemme, mi lor, is it I mus help you out?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: I had like to have been finely taken in here, La Poudre:—Emily is not Sir Thomas's daughter, but the parson's.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ah, morbleu! den I suppose she have peu on point d'argent, littel or no moneys —not so grande fortune as you did expeck?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: You have hit it—therefore I have declin'd marrying her as I intended, and offer'd (instead) to take her into keeping.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Vous avez raison, mi lor; 'tis ver vel juge—and she vil make ver pretty fille de joye for your keep, en verité.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Why, ay, La Poudre, tho' she is not freighted for a matrimonial voyage, she'd make a charming pleasure yatch! but she has refus'd that—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Refuse dat? la grande sotte! oh que de great a fool!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Her puppy of a brother just now interrupted me in an attempt upon her, and they are gone in doors to acquaint the family of it, I suppose—now, unless I can contrive to carry her off, I lose her for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Parbleu, c'est vrai, mi lor—it is ver true inteed.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: In hopes of which, you hear how I have order'd the carriage—now, if you think it possible to decoy her out, Robert and I will be ready to hurry her into it in a moment.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Je ne scai pas, mi lor—it vil be ver difficile—but I will try all my possibilité.

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: No matter what unaccountable lies you tell—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Lie! bygar I vil lie and swear thro' tick and thro' tin;

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: If you succeed, the moment she is without the garden door, do you bolt it within to prevent their tracing us; then climb over the wall directly, mount your horse, and scour away as if you rode for your life.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Oui, mi lor—but vere mus I scoure?

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Down to the beach as hard as ever you can ride, and hail the Tarquin—bid O'Connor bring the skiff ashore immediately, and both of you wait my coming to assist me.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Je vous entend bien, mi lor— and I sal scoure comme le diable!

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P: Then, if I get her but safe down there, I have no more to do but whisk her on board the Tarquin, put off to sea, and— [a noise heard without]

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Allez, allez, mi lor—somebody come—

SP.SPEAKER: L. Sealand.
SP.P:
I am gone—succeed, my dear La Poudre, and you are made for ever!—now,
Venus! be propitious to my scheme, I'll sail for Paphos, and there worship thee!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ma foi! it be de old gentilman himself come! parbleu, I no like his look—he is fort enragé—in one devil a great passion—mort de ma vie! I wish I no get break a my bone! fa, la, la, la, &c. [singing carelessly]

DIV2.STAGE: Sir Thomas Richacre and Dr. Goodman enter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Where is the rascal?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Fa, la, la, la!—who, sire?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: That scoundrel of a lord!—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Mi lor scoundrel? je ne scais pas —I am not acquaint vid mi lor Scoundrel, ni monsieur Rascal non plus! I have not de hon∣neur to know de gentilmens en verité—who do you mean, sire?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Mean, sire! why, when I ask for a scoundrel, a rascal, and a lord, who can I mean but Lord Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Mi lor Sealand!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Heaven forbid there should exist another lord, those names could be applied to!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Is the villain here yet, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I don't know where he is, not I, nor will this fellow tell me.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Parbleu! I am amaze! je vous en prie, gentilmens, vat is all dis fracas and tintamarre?—est ce que you dit ask a me, sire, vere be mi lor Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, who should I ask but you? do you think I enquir'd of the trees and flower-plots?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Je vous demande pardon, dat I ave no understand vat you speak ven you ask or mi lor Scoundrel—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well, now you do understand— where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Vat, mi lor Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Yes, you damn'd incomprehensible puppy! Lord Sealand.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Sire, he be only just valk littel way down de jardin.

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Down which walk?—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Down dat a walk, sire— [shew∣ing a wrong way]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Now then, if the villain has a heart, I'll put it to the proof! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
Sir Thom.
SP.P: He sha'n't be there long, a dog! nor in any other place that I am master of— for, as soon as I have told him what a scoun∣drel I think him, if he don't walk out of his own accord, I shall make bold to kick him out!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Kick him out! mort de ma vie! kick a mi lor Sealand? vat, in de name of vonder, all dis mean, sire?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: It means that your wicked lord has made a most infamous attempt upon my daughter's honour?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Your daughtere, sire!—vat daughtere?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Goodman.
SP.P: My Emily—my dear, my in∣nocent child!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Your shild, sire! be mademoiselle Emily your shild?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Goodman.
SP.P: She is! which that disgrace-to-his-rank no sooner knew, than (not content most poorly to reject her he had just before solicited for a wife) he wickedly endeavoured to seduce her to be his mistress!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Very wicked inteed, sire!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Nay more, to aggravate his guilt, proposed rewards for me, her wretched father! to be the pander to my daughter's infamy!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Helas! c'est une chose bien in∣fame et extraordinaire, inteed! I am quite shocka to hear it! I no mush vonder now de old gentilman be go kick a mi lor—but I vonder great deal you ave so mush patience and phi∣losophie dat you no go give him littel kick too, sire.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: 'Twould ill become my cloth to seek revenge—tho' I came here, I must con∣fess, in anger; and, had I met him, should have loaded him with bitterest reproaches— but, on reflection, think it better to avoid him —if he repents his fault, I am satisfied!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P:
'Tis very good of you inteed, sire—for mi lor ave been fort mechant, very naughty I mus confess; and I shou'd be no mush surprise if de young gentilman fight a mi lor and kill him—ecoutez!—hark a, mon∣sieur! I think I hear de sword clash—oh, que oui! dey fight! dey fight! ah, mon pauvre
lor! he vill be kill! he vill be kill! and I fall lose my place!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Kill'd! forbid it heaven! tho' he deserves the worst that could befall him, yet —let me endeavour to prevent more sin!

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! so far I ave tell de very pritty lie inteed, to get dem all out of de vay—now, vile de coast be cleare, I go to de maison, and try all my possibilité to get mademoiselle to mi lor—eh! parbleu, it vill be no politique to come back dis way and meet a les gentilshommes again! vat I sall do, ma foi!—let a me considere— [going]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: George—brother! where are you, my dear, cruel George?—

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Quel bonheur! here come de lady quite apropos!—now for de bold stroke— ah miserable que je suis! la peur me fait mourir! I am frighten to death! help a meurtre! meurtre!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Ah, murder? merciful heaven! I fear'd as much, and therefore followed— where? who?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ah, madame! I am frighten out of my sense! Young monsieur Goodaman be gone out of de gate of de jardin to fight a mi lor Sealand, and I justement hear de sword clash and pistol fire!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Gracious heaven defend him!—bro∣ther! father! help! murder! help!

DIV2.STAGE: Exit Emily the way L. Sealand went.

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! dat is bien fait —ver vell done inteed! [looking after her] you be goot girl, run ver vell—mi lor vill kesh you dans un moment, and carry you quite away! ha, ha, ha, ha!

DIV2.STAGE: Sir Thomas Richacre re-enters at the upper End of the Stage, looking about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Where, in the devil's name, has he hid himself?

SP.SPEAKER: La Poudre.
SP.P: Ah, ma foi! here come old gen∣tilman again! now I must run bolt a de jardin door apres mademoiselle, climb over de vall, (take care I no break a my neck tho') monter á cheval, and scoure down to de beeche as if de devil vas scoure after me!—ha, ha, ha, ha! bygar, I am von very greata devilish lucky rogue! ha, ha, ha, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: 'Tis in vain to seek him here, sir; he must certainly have returned up the yew∣tree walk to the house, while we have been this way, and may offer fresh insult to my sister—the thought alarms me!—let me fly to her protection!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
Why, there's no finding the dog any where, Doctor—he is not in the garden I'm sure—unless he has hid himself at the
bottom of the canal—I'll have it dragg'd, and if I find him there, I sha'n't have quite so bad an opinion of him as I had.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Let us hope, sir, he has reflected on the heinousness of his behaviour, and with∣drawn himself privately through shame.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Shame, a villain! he was not asham'd of committing the offence, but I sup∣pose he'd blush up to the eyes to ask pardon; nay, run the best friend he has in the world through the body, or blow his brains out, sooner than do it!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: It is to that false shame, sir, we may attribute most of the impious duels, by which our laws divine and human are daily scandaliz'd and broken!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, it's too true, Doctor—the more the pity!—come, George—heyday! what's gone with him?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: He went in doors to Emily, I be∣lieve, sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well—come, my good friend, let us forget this puppy that has vex'd us— 'thank heaven no harm came of it—I think we had e'en as well go tell your sweet girl what I was proposing, when George and she came in from Sealand; and have the wedding cele∣brated as soon as possible.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Dear sir, consider once more the vast disparity before you finally determine— the obligations you have conferr'd on me and mine already, are never to be cancell'd, but this unthought-of condescension—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P:
No more, no more, my dear old friend! I have considered it thoroughly, and (if you will so far indulge me) it shall be so—
we'll shew the libertine we can set a proper value upon merit, without the recommendation of fortune, tho' he cou'd not, by offering her a husband not much inferior to himself, who will love her and protect her!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Have you seen my sister, sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Not since we left her in the house; is she not there?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: No, sir! Patty says, that fearful of my having a rencounter with Lord Sealand, she follow'd me into the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Bless me! where can she have gone so suddenly?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why the devil's in the people to day, I think, i'my conscience—one can't turn one's head, but, like goblins and fairies, or a jugler's cups and balls, they're vanish'd!— Odzookers! now I think a little, my mind misgives me—sure that damn'd fellow, Sealand, has not convey'd her off!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Which way, dear sir? the garden door, you see, is shut, and fast bolted, which, if they had gone out of it, must have been left open.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, Emily! Sealand! French∣man! scoundrel!—where, in the devil's name, are you all got to? [running up and down the stage]

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Sir! sir! your worship!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What are you bawling about, you rascal? is not one enough at a time?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Your worship!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What does the blockhead stare so at? have you seen your young lady any where lately?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: N—n—no, your worship!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Nor Lord Sealand?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: N—n—no, sir! I ha'n't seen ne'er a one of them since tea-time—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Then what do you come to plague us now for, you puppy!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Lord, your honour! I only came to tell your worship the poor woman, Dame Quickset, that lives at the cottage where your honours all went after dinner to day, is begging for dear life to speak to your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I am busy now—I can't speak to her—zounds! I cou'd not speak to the great mogul if he was here—why, Emily! Sealand!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Dear sir, be patient for a moment —it may be something concerning my child— pray let her speak with you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Quick.
SP.P: Where is his good worship? I must speak with un, for it be upon life and death! [she enters] O, heaven bless your wor∣ship! you're undone! you're undone!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: So I have been just thinking!— but how, how?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Quick.
SP.P: Young madam! your daughter! your daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What of her!—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Speak! speak!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Where is she, good woman, where is she?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Quick.
SP.P: Heaven knows where by this, not I!—some vile villains have kidnap'd the pre∣cious lady away, to have their wicked will of her; or else (for the lucre of gold) to sell her for a neger-slave, or a turk, I do verily believe!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: A negro or a turk! why what a plague does the woman mean?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Quick.
SP.P: Why, an't please your worship, a strange outlandish looking man came galloping down our lane not a minute agone, whipping and spurring poor beast like any mad! and a fine chariot came driving a'ter him from your worship's garden door, as thof 'twou'd ha' tore the ground to very bits; with somebody screaming and crying i'th' inside on't as thof they had been murder'd! and, as it pass'd by our hut, who should I see it was but the sweet young Lady Richacre, your worship's daughter, with some vile rogue sitting beside and holding her, disguised like a gentleman!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: As sure as death it was that dog Sealand!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Good heaven protect my child!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Follow me, William! and help to get arms and horses ready!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Od rot un! I'll take blunderbuss from hall-chimney for myself, and, if I come up with un, I'll make un remember the day o'the month I warrant un!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Metre! John! Coachman I saddle all the horses! load all the fire arms! raise the whole county! blood! I'll blow the villains all to pieces!

DIV2.HEAD: ACT V. Scene, a Parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: PATTY.
SP.P: DEAR heart, how I tremble! I am sadly afraid they won't overtake them—lud, lud! I wish somebody was come back again, for I begin to be afraid to stay in the house any longer—who knows but they'll come and run away with me next! O, I wish William was come back! I hope the dear soul won't come to any harm!—lud, lud! what a twitter am I in!—and what can have become of my father?—sure he has not follow'd them a-foot —hark! did not I hear a noise? perhaps I forgot to fasten the hall-door in my fright, and somebody is coming to run away with me!

DIV2.STAGE: Metre enters out of breath, she runs and embraces him.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: O dear father! is it you? I am glad you are come back!—where have you been? what have you heard? have you seen any thing of them?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: What! hath no one returned yet, Martha?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Nobody but you, father.—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P:
Goodlack! goodlack! was there ever the like heard of! neither tale nor tidings can I learn, and I have run up and down al∣most
every lane in the parish, untill my poor old legs are just ready to drop off!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: You had better sit down, father, and rest yourself, while I get something for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Sit down, child? no, I will neither eat, nor drink, nor rest, untill the precious lady is found!—I wanted but to know if any one had been more prosperous than myself, before I journeyed to any vast distance; and since no one hath, I will travel unto the world's end, but I will find her!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Pray, dear father, don't—for, if you should chance to meet with the villains, they may murder you, and then come and run away with me!—indeed I can't stay here any longer by myself with such dreadful apprehensions— O! I am terrified out of my senses!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Be composed, my good child—they must be hardened wretches indeed to slay a poor old man like me, who could assail them with nought but prayers and supplications— therefore, make fast the door after me, and look heedfully unto the mansion, child, while I— [going]—as I am a sinner, my reverend master is returned!—I pray heaven he bringeth joyful tidings!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Ha? what's that I hear? joyful tidings, said you? is she found, Metre? is she found?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: No, truly, if your reverence hath not been so prosperous!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Distraction! O my child! my lost, lost, violated child!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: The Philistines are come upon her, verily!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Here, Patty! where are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Lord! here's his worship come back, sir—who knows but he may have had better luck —I am in great hopes—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: No, no, no! there are no hopes! no hopes!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Patty! Metre!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Here, your worship!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Who's at home? has nobody found this rascal yet? nobody return'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Yes, an't please your worship, his reverence is returned, and so am I.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And so are you!—why I did not know you had been any where—where the devil did you hide yourself? I call'd and bawl'd for you before I went out 'till I was hoarse again, but could not find you.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Indeed, your worship, my poor father has been running all over the parish, seeking for young madam, 'till he is almost dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well! and has he found her?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Oh, no, no, no!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why then I wish he was quite dead —and I wish I was dead—and we were all dead! and buried! and—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Good your worship wax not wroth with your poor old servant! I did my best, in truth; and was just going to repeat my feeble endeavours as his reverence came in.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Dear sir, advise me—I am almost distracted!—what shall I do? where shall I seek her?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I know no more than you—almost distracted, quotha? zounds! I have been stark mad this half hour!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Will your good worship please to repose you in your easy chair?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Repose the devil!—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Mercy on us!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Which way did you go, Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I went first, sir, to Lord Sealand's house—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Psha! that I know already, for I was there just after you—what could induce you to go there? you might be sure enough he would not carry her home—which way did George go?

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: I know not, sir—heaven will, I hope, direct him better!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: He can't have worse luck than I had go which way he will—for, so far from a coach or a chariot, I could not see so much as a cart or a wheel-barrow—but, come, come—don't let us stand chattering here—let us go look somewhere or other— [going]

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P:
Hilli ho! my hearts!—what cheer, honies?—what, all under hatches? tumble up, tumble up, my jewels!— [he enters] By my
soul! this is the strangest vessel I ever stuck foot aboard—the devil a hand is there walking deck to keep watch! so, fait, I e'en made bold to take a peep into the cabin!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Who the devil are you, sir? what do you want here?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Arrah, be easy, my jewel! don't put yourself out of your latitude, and you'll know who I am presently—but why won't you station a hand upon deck yonder to keep a bit of a look out? or you may be boarded by a land-pirate, honey!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Go, Martha, and make fast the door, child.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Dear heart! I am almost afraid this strange man is come to run away with me! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What's your business? what do you want of me?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: What do I want with you? the devil a toothful do I want of you, but a little civil discourse; nor that neither, unless you are the commander here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Well, sir, I am the commander as you call it—What then?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Why then—I'll lower my top-sail to you, honey! [pulling off his hat]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: But—what's your business? for I'm in haste—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Why you are to know, joy, I am just come full sail upon the outside of a horse (with another in tow) from the salt-sea-shore, to bring you advice of a sweet cratur, a female young woman, (belonging here) and my master Lord Sealand—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Lord Scoundrel!—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Indeed you may say that—more pity the two words should ever be splic'd to∣gether!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: But your news, sir, your news!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Why, you must know, I receav'd orders from Mounseer Powder-puff, my lord's walley-de-shaver, to have our skiff ready to carry my lord, and the young woman I mention'd, aboard our cutter, the Tarquin—but I soon found, by her unwillingness, that she was not a volunteer of her own accord; but had been press'd into the sarvice without giving her con∣sent to it—so, faith! I began to be a little queer with my lord about it; for the sweet cratur look'd as innocent as a sucking dove, ay, or a new-born dove's egg! and I determin'd not to aid and assist at making her otherwise!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Eternal blessings on you for your goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Devil a goodness in the case, honey —'twas no more than the duty of every honest man that is not a rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Give me your hand, my heart of oak! I am your friend for ever!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: So, while we were raving and squabbling within half a cable's length of land, a good clever likely young jontleman, and a carrotty-pated livery-servant, came galloping and splashing into the salt-sea, as if they were riding post over to France or Holland! for their horses were fairly afloat, and half way to the skiff in the turning of a handspike.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: So, friend!—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P:
Hollo! you young harebrains! says I—have a care you don't run foul of our
little nut-shell, and spill us all! upon which the poor girl cry'd out, it was her brother!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Her brother!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Devil fire me! says little Brian O'Connor (that's myself) if their beasts shall board us, and send us to the bottom, if he was your brother and sister too! but, do you hear, young jontleman? says I, have a little wit in your folly, and don't fink your friends and your foes together, but take in a reef a two and we'll be alongside you presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: That was right, friend, that was right!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Upon which, you may take your swear, my bug-of-a-lord did all he could to prevent my carrying the boat ashore—and, at last, when he found nothing else would do, (nor that neither) was trying to hussle me overboard—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Was it possible!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Indeed it was not!—for, as soon as I perceav'd it, Oho! thinks little Brian, are you for that fun? I'll be bound I match you to a tittle, my jewel! so, upon my conscience, I made no more ceremony, but gave him as pretty a genteel lift as you shall see in a sum∣mer's day, and capsiz'd him (souse!) headlong into the wet ocean! where he look'd, for all the world, like the gold and filver fish folks keep in glass washing-rubs!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha! well done, well done, i'faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: But (notwithstanding his demerits) he was not drowned, sir, I hope!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: There we differ, old Stave, for once—for I hope he was.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: No, faith, sir, as ill luck would have it, he was not drown'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: The more the pity, say I.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Upon my conscience, sir, you say very right—it was God's mercy and a thousand pities sure enough! but I take it he was a little damp or so, for when he scrambled ashore, the salt brine ran from him by pailfuls.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha, ha, ha, ha! I shall burst, I shall burst! upon second thoughts I am glad the dog was not drown'd, for if he had, I should have been kill'd outright.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Yes, fait, and so would he too!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: But how ended the matter, pray sir?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: O, it was soon over, honey! for when I had thrown the whale into Jonas's belly—

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Jonas into the whale's belly, I apprehend you mean, sir!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Well! the whale into Jonas, or Jonas into the whale, it's all one an't it? —when I had given my lord a summerset, I say, and spilt him into the ocean, we got ashore presently—but, as the young jontleman was hoisting his sister out of the boat, his draggle-tail'd lordship lent him such a pat o'the cheek, as was enough to break his hand∣some face, or put one of his forecastle lights out!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: The cowardly villain! but he re∣paid it, I hope?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P:
Och! I'll be bound he did—and with interest too—for he had the honour of horse-whipping his lordship to his heart's con∣tent! and (by way of premium) I divarted
myself the mean time with beating his impu∣dent French walley-de-shaver!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Bravo! bravo! ha, ha, ha! but what became of the livery-servant all this while? sure he was not idle?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: What, the lad with the bunch of carrots growing on his head? indeed he was not—for he had no sooner handed the poor frighted girl out of the gangway, and brought the two horses they went, and I came upon, to an anchor; but the tight lad beseag'd the coach-box, took it by storm, and is now piloting the young jontleman and lady safe into port here, aboard my lord's own chariot, fait: leaving him and his rascally companions to pad the hoof, and trudge home upon their ten toes!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Odso! then let's go meet 'em! they can't be far off by this, and I long to see the dear rogues again— [going]—hark! sure I hear a carriage stop.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: My lady's come back, sir! my lady's come back! young Mr. Goodman and William have found her, and they are all come back together!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Rejoice and sing! kill the fatted calf and be merry, for the lost sheep is found!

DIV2.STAGE: She runs to Dr. Goodman, Sir Thomas Richacre catches George in his arms.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: My dear, dear, brave boy! thou'rt welcome home again!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [to Dr. Goodman] O my lov'd sire! scarce did I know my father, ere I was torn from him! but am restor'd (thank heaven!) to his paternal arms!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Thanks, gracious providence! I see my child again!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Amen!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Odzookers! George! I have been in a plaguy pucker about you, you rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I am eternally bound to you for this solicitude! And, was not my dear father exceedingly alarm'd? [to Dr. Goodman]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Alarm'd! why I tell you I have been almost out of my wits about you both!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir, I am bound to you for ever! but, my dear father— [to Dr. Goodman]—is not he happy too that my sister, his sweet daughter, is safe restored?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, that he is, I'll answer for him—and, as you have so bravely help'd to recover a daughter for him, the least he can do in return is to provide you with a father, by restoring me my son!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Sir! what does my patron say?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Say?—ecod I don't know what to say?—only that, in having you for my heir, I am father to one of the best and bravest lads in the kingdom!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Father—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Yes, my dear boy! I am indeed! —your father! George, your father! [embracing him] Odzookers, Doctor, I could contain my∣self no longer, faith!

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: Dear sir, he is your own, and truly worth the claiming!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Indulgent powers! is it possible? [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: O good gracious! ma'am! here's good news for you. [aside to Emily]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Wonderful! wonderful! most won∣derful!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Am I in a dream!—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Upon my conscience I can't tell— but, if you are, you have had a very pleasant ride in your sleep!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Dear sirs! what am I to think?— within these few hours I thought myself the son of this worthy divine, and this sweet maid, your daughter, sir— [to Sir Thomas Richacre] we then were wretched beyond idea, supposing our∣selves the issue of one parent! and now, sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And now, my dear boy! all is set right—you are my son, my own flesh and blood! at least your mother, Lady Richacre, (who was a pattern of conjugal fidelity) told me so—and Emily is as surely Dr. Goodman's daughter. [George kneels to Sir Thomas, who raises and embraces him]

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Transporting sounds! then we may yet be happy! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Devil burn me! but this makes out the old saying good—that it's a wise father knows his own child—O no, fait, I don't mean so neither—(tho' that may be true too) but, it's a wise child knows it's own father!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Most honour'd parent! [to Sir Tho∣mas] (if I really am so blest) may I presume to ask why we have both been bred in such a mutual error?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: I'll tell thee, George—I had ob∣serv'd, with great concern, how seldom young men, bred in the insolent pride of inheriting great estates, deserv'd them!—I am a whimsical old fellow, you know—and therefore proposed to, and prevail'd on, my respected friend (as we became widowers almost together) to join with me in a project I had formed (in imita∣tion of the Spectator's Leontine and Eudoxus) of exchanging children for a time—hoping thereby to render you more worthy than you might otherwise have been, of the fortune and title you was born to—the experiment was a singular one, I own, but the event has fully justified it! [George bows]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And, sir!—if I dare ask one question more—what recompence did you purpose to this young lady for being deluded with such an imaginary grandeur?

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Bless me! what is he saying? [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Was it to realize the golden dream?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why, I had some such notion, indeed, George.—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: If I remember right the story you alluded to, sir, the good, the generous Eudoxus, join'd the young and loving pair: is that my sire's intention? or (which I dread to ask!)— is it to—marry her yourself?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ha? what! marry Emily myself? bless her dear little heart, heaven forbid! no, no, I had a younger spark in my eye for her—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Benignity itself! he means my George, I'm certain, and I shall yet be blest! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Then, sir, I may speak plainer—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: What will the dear youth say! [aside]

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And declare, that I am vet a beggar, if you add not to my late acquisition of for∣tune, the supreme delight of restoring this lov'd maid to the station she was bred in, by per∣mitting me still to call this best of men my father!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What do you ask me for? she's none of mine, you fool! why don't you ask the Doctor?

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: [to Sir Thomas] My indulgent fa∣ther! [to Dr. Goodman] O, sir! either my behaviour has hitherto been unfilial, or you will kindly receive me for your son again.

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: My ever dearest son!—take her, and may heaven shower down eternal blessings on you both!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Amen!—

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Ay, and so be it too, say I!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Now, if my Emily thinks me not unworthy—

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: O talk not so! 'tis I that am unwor∣thy—yet wherefore?—if desert consisted but in riches, then I were indeed deficient! but, conscious of a mind superior to the distinctions of birth and fortune, I feel that I deserve your love! for, had our conditions really been as we imagined, preferring thee, the worthiest, to the most wealthy, I should have gloried in my acquisition more than in a conquest of the most exalted!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: I know it, my sweet Emily! I know it.

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P:
And, if my preserver loves like me, he will not ask, but take my trembling hand;
assur'd, that he possesses wholly my fond, my beating heart!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: Thus then I take thy snowy hand! here seal my faith! [kissing her hand] and hence∣forth we are one!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Ay, and a very pretty splice you have both made on't!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: [to Sir Thomas] I have so full a sense, sir, of your most unexampled goodness, in first adopting your poor girl, and now confirming thus your favour, I cannot thank you as I ought!—let these duteous, grateful tears speak for me! [falling on her knee]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Rise, rise, my sweet child! you are my daughter now indeed! [raises and kisses her]

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: [wiping his eyes] Well! I wish I may never taste another cheekful of beef and biscuit, or a sup of grog again, if this is not as pretty a piece of business—

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: My good friend! the preserver of my Emily! amid these several transports I have too long overlook'd you!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P:
Och! no offence, gra! I have been overlooking you too, 'till I don't know what ails me fait! but I've a notion the salt-water that spalpeen of a lord splash'd in my face when I tilted him overboard, had not got out of the corners of my eyes before! for some drops trickled down the scuppers of my cheeks into my mouth just now that tasted quite brackish! they could not be tears sure! for (tho' we Irishmen are apt to make blunders) a
weather-beaten chap like myself would not cry, sure, at what he's so well pleas'd with!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: You have a double title to my gratitude, as I receiv'd assistance from you against your own master; not fearing, in the cause of virtue, to offend the wretch you serv'd!

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: I'll tell you what, honey!—Saint Patrick be thankful, I'm never afraid of doing what's right!—for tho' I'm but a menial man of low degree, I am sprung from a very great offspring, and have got the thick blood of the kings of Ireland bubbling in my veins, joy!— and, in my foolish way of thinking, so far from offending, I sarv'd my master most faithfully by not sarving him at all at all, in such an unjontlemanlike undertaking!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: You are a right honest tar! and shall never serve any one again while you live.

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Indeed and I will always sarve both you and yours with all the blood in my bones!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: How, or in what words shall I ex∣press my very fervent thanks to you, for hav∣ing sav'd a helpless creature from what I dread to think of! [to O'Connor]

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: I'll tell you how you shall thank me, jewel! by holding your sweet tongue, and never saying another word about it!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: Generous man! my deeds shall then speak for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: Dear father! now every thing else is settled so nicely, do, pray, put in a word for poor William.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: And yourself, eh, Martha?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: If you please, father.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Well, I will adventure to address their honours—hem! hem! good your wor∣ship!—and good your reverence!—this seem∣ing an auspicious hour, your poor old servant hath an humble boon to crave.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: What is it, old silver-locks?

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: That it may please your honours, when the bans of matrimony are published between my dear and honourable young master and mistress, (as I trust his reverence will not approve they should be married by licence) the names of my poor child, Martha Metre, spinster—and her chosen spouse and helpmate, William Strongbow, batchelor, both of this parish, may be permitted most humbly to follow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: William Strongbow! what, young carrotty-poll? where is the red-headed rogue? I have not seen him since he scal'd the coach-box.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: He is in the hall, I believe, father! [aside to him]

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: William Strongbow! approach his worship's presence.

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: Did your worship please to want me?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Ay, come hither, William—I am told you have behav'd like a man of Kent to day, in helping to rescue my maid of Kent here from Lord Sealand and his myrmidons?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I did my best, an't like your wor∣ship, as I was in duty bound.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And likewise that you and Patty want to make a match together?

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: If your worship and his reverence please to give us leave. [bowing]

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: What say you, Patty?

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: William has spoke my mind, your honours! [curtsying]

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Why then marry away, you young rogues, as fast as you can! you have my good∣will.

SP.SPEAKER: Metre, William, and Patty.
SP.P: I humbly thank your wor∣ship!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: And mine!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre, William, and Patty.
SP.P: I humbly thank your reve∣rence!—

SP.SPEAKER: Dr. Good.
SP.P: And I pray heaven to bless and prosper you!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Amen!—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: And in reward for your service to day, I'll make a man of you, my boy!

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: I most humbly thank your noble worship's honour and goodness!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P: And, with your leave, sir, I will give Patty a little portion.

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: 'Thank you kindly, sir! and may you and my dear young lady be as happy together as you deserve!

SP.SPEAKER: Emily.
SP.P: I thank you, Patty!—may you, [to Patty and William] and every virtuous pair be no less so!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: Amen!—

SP.SPEAKER: William.
SP.P: And now, Patty, we shall be as merry as grigs, or as midsummer-day is long!

SP.SPEAKER: Patty.
SP.P: That we shall, William! and I long for the wedding to be over, that, instead of plain Patty, I may hear myself call'd Mrs. Strongbow!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Thom.
SP.P: Now, I believe, all parties are re∣warded and satisfied, except the poor Quicksets; and they too shall partake the happiness they, by the timely alarm given us, were in great measure the means of, and never be poor, or want for any thing again, unless it be health, and that the richest of us can't bestow! And so, every thing is settled, and we are all hap∣py! are we not, old boy? shake hands, my heart of oak! what say you?

SP.SPEAKER: O'Connor.
SP.P: Why, sir, I say—the honour of wagging a fist with you wou'd make the happy if I was ever so miserable! but I'm after think∣ing the young jontleman and his little sweet∣lips there, ay, and t'other young couple too, won't be quite easy 'till they have shook hands and been splic'd together in church, fait!

SP.SPEAKER: George.
SP.P:
The idea transports me!—my Emily!—my destin'd bride! we now approach the height of human bliss! blest as we are in the paternal care of these our best of fathers, the affections of our faithful friends and ser∣vants, and the fruition of our mutual disin∣terested love!—the vices of that miscreant lord, you happily was delivered from, are pu∣nished by an indelible disgrace! while the
virtues of this circle are rewarded with a per∣fect, and, I hope 'twill prove, a lasting felicity!

SP.SPEAKER: Metre.
SP.P: AMEN!

L.HI: OUR silly author fain would have me speak
Something I understand no more than Greek;
His epilogue—which he, sure, thinks as fine
As if inspir'd by Phoebus and the Nine!

LG.L: Such moral lessons—sage, instructive rules—

L.HI: Drawn from learn'd folios, and the antient schools.
Morals, said I, the schools, and huge dull folios?
Why, sir, these sort of things should be quite olios!
Compos'd of choice tid-bits cull'd up and down,

LG.L: From the gay fancies that amuse this town—

L.HI: With scavoir-vivres let your scene be laid,
Tell us of coteries, or a masquerade;
Of such materials epilogues are made!
Yet still he begs that I would plead his cause,
And say, "the piece conforms to critic laws
In scene, time, action; and his further plan
To draw men as they are, not more than man,
Some good, some bad"—thus tritely on he ran.
Preach this yourself for me, sir, I replied,
An epilogue I want where may be tried
My comic talents, after this dull part,

LG.L: Which was not worth the getting off by heart—

L.HI: Give me a taste of gay Thalia's art!
In witty verse to satirize the beaux,
And swear they know no bliss beyond fine cloaths:

LG.L: While smirking—leering—playing with my fan—

L.HI: I may attract each modish, ape of man,
And make him feel—if feel such beings can.
Speak scandal of the ladies—say the cits
Have hearty stomachs, and but puny wits;
Nay, any thing to please and to amuse

LG.L: This gen'rous circle—politics or news;—

L.HI: Joyful I'd come, on such an errand sent,

LG.L: And you still more approv'd The MAID of KENT!
